item.title: CTE
item.description: A Common Table Expression (CTE) is a temporary, named result set defined within the scope of a single SQL statement. Introduced by the WITH keyword, a CTE helps improve query readability, maintainability, and modularity by allowing you to break down complex queries into smaller, more understandable parts. WITH cte_name AS ( SELECT ... FROM ... WHERE ... ) SELECT ... FROM cte_name; cte_name: A name you assign to the temporary result set. The code inside the parentheses ( ... ) is essentially a subquery that you can reference multiple times in the main query. A CTE is defined before the main query using the WITH clause. Once defined, the CTE acts as a virtual table that exists just for the execution of that query. After the main query finishes running, the CTE no longer exists. It is not persistent or stored in the database schema. Improved Readability and Organization: CTEs allow you to isolate complex logic from the main query. Instead of writing one large, nested query, you can define logical steps within separate CTEs and then reference them, making your SQL code easier to understand and maintain. Reusability within the Same Query: Once defined, you can reference the CTE multiple times within the main query. This can help avoid repeating the same subquery logic multiple times. Multiple CTEs in a Single Query: You can define multiple CTEs separated by commas and then select from them in the final query. This allows for building a sequence of computations step-by-step. Recursive Queries: Some databases support recursive CTEs, which enable you to solve hierarchical or tree-like data structures easily. Recursive CTEs repeatedly reference themselves until a stopping condition is met. WITH EmployeeSalaries AS ( SELECT EmployeeID, FirstName, LastName, Salary, DepartmentID FROM Employees WHERE Salary > 50000 ) SELECT * FROM EmployeeSalaries ORDER BY Salary DESC; Explanation: The CTE EmployeeSalaries extracts employees with a salary over 50,000. The main query then selects from EmployeeSalaries as if it were a regular table. This approach improves clarity compared to embedding the SELECT logic directly in the FROM clause. CTE: Declared using WITH at the start of the statement. Can be referenced multiple times in the subsequent query. Often more readable and easier to maintain. Subquery: Defined inline, usually nested in SELECT, FROM, or WHERE clauses. Each occurrence must be repeated if the logic is needed multiple times. Can make queries harder to read when multiple subqueries are nested. WITH HighEarner AS ( SELECT EmployeeID, FirstName, LastName, Salary FROM Employees WHERE Salary > 70000 ), DepartmentSummary AS ( SELECT DepartmentID, COUNT(*) AS TotalEmployees FROM Employees GROUP BY DepartmentID ) SELECT h.FirstName, h.LastName, h.Salary, d.TotalEmployees FROM HighEarner h JOIN DepartmentSummary d ON h.DepartmentID = d.DepartmentID; Explanation: The first CTE (HighEarner) identifies employees with a salary above 70,000. The second CTE (DepartmentSummary) calculates how many employees are in each department. The main SELECT statement then joins these two CTEs, producing a result that shows each high-earning employee along with the total count of employees in their department. (If supported by your SQL dialect, such as PostgreSQL or SQL Server)WITH RECURSIVE OrgChart AS ( SELECT EmployeeID, ManagerID, FirstName, LastName FROM Employees WHERE ManagerID IS NULL -- start from the top-level manager(s) UNION ALL SELECT e.EmployeeID, e.ManagerID, e.FirstName, e.LastName FROM Employees e JOIN OrgChart o ON e.ManagerID = o.EmployeeID ) SELECT * FROM OrgChart; Explanation: This recursive CTE starts by selecting top-level managers (those with no ManagerID). In the recursive part (after UNION ALL), it repeatedly selects employees whose ManagerID matches an EmployeeID already found in OrgChart, building the hierarchy level by level. CTEs and Optimization: Most relational databases treat CTEs like inline views. Depending on the database, a CTE might or might not be materialized (cached). While CTEs are great for readability, they do not inherently guarantee performance improvements. In some cases, a well-tuned subquery or a different approach may be faster. Indexing: Since CTEs are not physical tables, you cannot index them directly. They rely on indexes on the underlying tables. Complex Queries: When you have a complex query that would benefit from breaking down logic into steps. Repetition Avoidance: When the same logic or computation needs to be reused multiple times in a query. Recursive Solutions: When dealing with hierarchical data and you need a simple way to traverse parent-child relationships. CTEs are powerful tools for structuring queries in a clear, modular fashion. They simplify complex SQL statements, enhance readability, and can provide a more logical flow when dealing with intricate logic or hierarchical data. While not always a performance enhancement, their primary value lies in cleaner, more maintainable SQL code.
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Subqueries, Correlated subqueries
item.description: Subqueries (also known as inner queries) are queries nested inside other SQL statements, such as SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE. They allow you to dynamically use the results of one query as input or conditions for another. Correlated subqueries are a special type of subquery that references one or more columns from the outer query. Unlike a regular subquery, a correlated subquery is evaluated once for each row processed by the outer query, making it more dynamic but potentially less performant. A subquery is a query enclosed in parentheses and embedded inside a larger query. It is often used in WHERE clauses, FROM clauses (as a derived table), or SELECT clauses. Generally, a subquery can be executed independently, and its result is then passed to the outer query. Filtering Results in a WHERE Clause: SELECT EmployeeID, FirstName, LastName FROM Employees WHERE DepartmentID = ( SELECT DepartmentID FROM Departments WHERE DepartmentName = 'Sales' ); Explanation: The subquery finds the DepartmentID for the "Sales" department. The outer query then returns all employees in that department. Using Subqueries in the FROM Clause (Derived Tables): SELECT d.DepartmentName, e.EmployeeCount FROM ( SELECT DepartmentID, COUNT(*) AS EmployeeCount FROM Employees GROUP BY DepartmentID ) e INNER JOIN Departments d ON d.DepartmentID = e.DepartmentID; Explanation: The subquery e aggregates employees by department. The outer query joins this result to the Departments table to retrieve department names alongside employee counts. Subqueries in the SELECT List: SELECT FirstName, LastName, (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM Orders WHERE Orders.EmployeeID = Employees.EmployeeID) AS OrderCount FROM Employees; Explanation: For each employee, the subquery counts how many orders they have processed. Typically executed once, and the result is reused by the outer query. Does not necessarily depend on the outer queryâ€™s current row. In other words, the subquery can stand alone and run independently. A correlated subquery is a subquery that references columns from the outer (parent) query. It means the subquery depends on the current row of the outer query to be evaluated. As a result, a correlated subquery is executed once for each row in the outer query, making it more computationally expensive in many cases. SELECT e.EmployeeID, e.FirstName, e.LastName FROM Employees e WHERE e.Salary > ( SELECT AVG(Salary) FROM Employees e2 WHERE e2.DepartmentID = e.DepartmentID ); Explanation: For each employee e in the outer query, the correlated subquery (SELECT AVG(Salary) FROM Employees e2 WHERE e2.DepartmentID = e.DepartmentID) calculates the average salary for that employeeâ€™s department. Thus, the subquery depends on e.DepartmentID, a value in the outer query, changing the subqueryâ€™s criteria as the outer query progresses through its rows. The outer query selects a row. The correlated subquery runs, using values from that row, and returns a result. The outer query uses that result to determine if the row meets the conditions. This process repeats for each row of the outer queryâ€™s result set. Because a correlated subquery runs once per outer row, it can be much slower on large datasets. In many cases, it can be optimized by rewriting the query using joins, temporary tables, or window functions. Identify When Correlated Subqueries Are Necessary: If your logic requires a per-row lookup that depends on the outer row, a correlated subquery might be needed. For example, checking if an employeeâ€™s salary is greater than the average salary of their department (calculated at runtime). Optimize Correlated Subqueries: Consider rewriting the query using JOINs, COMMON TABLE EXPRESSIONS (CTEs), or window functions if possible. Example transformation using a CTE and a join: WITH DeptAvgSalary AS ( SELECT DepartmentID, AVG(Salary) AS AvgDeptSalary FROM Employees GROUP BY DepartmentID ) SELECT e.EmployeeID, e.FirstName, e.LastName FROM Employees e JOIN DeptAvgSalary das ON e.DepartmentID = das.DepartmentID WHERE e.Salary > das.AvgDeptSalary; This avoids the per-row computation and might run faster. Indexing for Performance: If you cannot avoid correlated subqueries, ensure that the columns used in the subqueryâ€™s conditions are indexed, which can mitigate performance issues. Subqueries and correlated subqueries are powerful SQL techniques that allow for sophisticated queries without overly complex joins or intermediate tables. Regular subqueries are independent and can be used to filter, aggregate, or create derived tables for the outer query. Correlated subqueries depend on the outer query and are evaluated once per row, making them more flexible but potentially less performant. When properly understood and applied, these constructs can simplify SQL logic and help you write more dynamic and powerful queries.
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: WINDOW
item.description: A window function is a special type of SQL function that performs calculations across a set of rows related to the current row. Unlike aggregate functions, which collapse multiple rows into a single output row, window functions return a result for every row in the queried set, while still allowing for row-by-row computations over a specified "window" of data. The "window" is a logical partition of the query result set. You define it using the OVER clause, which typically includes: PARTITION BY: Divides the data into groups (partitions) based on one or more columns. Each partition is processed independently by the window function. ORDER BY: Defines the logical order of rows within each partition, enabling functions to reference preceding or following rows. Do Not Collapse Rows: Unlike GROUP BY aggregates, window functions produce an output row for every input row. Each row retains its detail while still benefitting from aggregate-like calculations. Reference Multiple Rows: They can access "neighboring" rowsâ€™ data relative to the current row. For example, LAG() and LEAD() retrieve values from preceding or following rows, while ranking functions assign a rank or a row number within each partition. Flexible Calculations: Window functions enable running totals, moving averages, cumulative sums, and advanced statistical computations without complex self-joins or subqueries. Aggregate Functions as Window Functions: AVG(), SUM(), COUNT(), MAX(), MIN() When used with OVER(), these functions can produce cumulative sums or rolling averages. Ranking Functions: RANK(), DENSE_RANK(), ROW_NUMBER() Assign rankings to rows within partitions, useful for top-N queries, ordered subsets, and pagination. Value Functions: LAG() and LEAD() Allow you to compare current row values to prior or subsequent row values. Useful for trend analysis, price changes, or time-series comparisons. Analytical Functions: NTILE(), FIRST_VALUE(), LAST_VALUE() Create buckets of data or identify boundary values within each partition. Calculating a Running Total:SELECT EmployeeID, Sales, SUM(Sales) OVER (ORDER BY SalesDate) AS RunningTotal FROM DailySales; Explanation: For each row, SUM(Sales) OVER (ORDER BY SalesDate) calculates the cumulative sales up to that point in time, without losing the granularity of the individual rows. Determining a Rowâ€™s Position Within a Partition:SELECT DepartmentID, EmployeeID, Salary, RANK() OVER (PARTITION BY DepartmentID ORDER BY Salary DESC) AS SalaryRank FROM Employees; Explanation: For each department, employees are ranked by their salary. Employees with the highest salary in each department receive a rank of 1. Although not required for every window function, a window frame allows you to further specify the subset of rows considered by the function relative to the current row. For example: SELECT EmployeeID, Salary, AVG(Salary) OVER ( ORDER BY HireDate ROWS BETWEEN 2 PRECEDING AND CURRENT ROW ) AS MovingAvgSalary FROM Employees; This considers only the current row and the two rows before it when calculating the average. Window functions can simplify queries and often perform more efficiently than equivalent self-joins or subqueries. Proper indexing on partitioning and ordering columns can further improve performance. Window functions are powerful analytical tools that enhance SQLâ€™s capability to perform complex calculations without losing the detail of individual rows. By leveraging PARTITION BY, ORDER BY, and optional window frames, you can write sophisticated analytical queries for time-series data, financial reporting, and other data analysis tasks.
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 2. Progress Update
item.description: distribution rights exclusive license reach an agreement term sheet final draft agreement We had a meeting this pas Monday to discuss some outstanding issues on the table. Theyâ€™re trying to play hardball. Hopefully weâ€™ll square away any remaining issues then. Hello, Yangha! The sentences you said sound really good! Just a few minor adjustments and they'll be even more natural English sentences. In the first sentence, "By the end of two year.", you should say "two years" instead of "two year". "Year" is a plural noun, so you need to use "years"! In the second sentence, "We need to negotiate for suppliers for hardware supplies.", you can remove "for" and say "We need to negotiate with suppliers for hardware supplies." It sounds more natural. "Negotiate with" means "í˜‘ìƒí•˜ë‹¤", and using "with" instead of "for" is a more natural expression. In the third sentence, "We have to delay all the schedule.", it would be better to say "We have to delay the whole schedule." In Korean, "all" is often used to mean "ì „ì²´", but in English, "the whole" is more natural. In the fourth sentence, "I had a project to build database.", you need to add "a" before "database" to say "I had a project to build a database." "Database" is a countable noun, so you need to add "a" in front of it. In the last sentence, "They are not enough to build database by themselves.", you can replace "enough" with "sufficient" and say "They are not sufficient to build database by themselves." "Enough" should be used as an adjective, and "sufficient" is more natural as a noun. Yangha, if you carefully review each sentence and practice, you'll be able to develop even better English skills! By the end of the year We need to negotiate for suppliers for hardware supplies. â†’ We need to negotiate with suppliers for hardware procurement. We have to delay all the schedule. â†’ We need to delay all schedules. I had a project to build database. â†’ I worked on project to build a database. They are not enough to build database by themselves. â†’They donâ€™t have enough expertise to build a database independently.
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 16. Structuring a Discussion
item.description: look to expand the business into SWOT analysis product line investment opportunity The first item on the agenda is to discuss this SWOT analysis prepared by our analysts. Do you have any thoughts on the information presented in the report? Letâ€™s set aside this topic for now and think about this a bit more before we make a final decision. Hello, everyone. Today, weâ€™re here to explore ways to boost our smartphone sales in the U.S. The first item on our agenda is reviewing our pricing strategy. Next, weâ€™ll discuss distribution channelsâ€”whether to switch, expand, or optimize them. Finally, weâ€™ll talk about how to enhance our marketing efforts. Letâ€™s start with the first topic: our pricing strategy. Do you have any thoughts on? Q. When you hold meetings, which types of items do you generally like to discuss first? Why?A. I usually set the first item as either the most important or the most controversial topic to ensure everyone is focused right from the start. However, this approach can vary depending on the purpose of the meeting. For instance, if I know someone critical to the discussion wonâ€™t be able to join on time, I might postpone the important item until later. Ultimately, the order of the agenda depends on the specific circumstances and goals of the meeting.Q. Which items do you generally postpone for discussion later?A. The item that we need a time to figure out, or needed to research. If i judged that there are need of time for other people to figure out about the topic, I may postpone that for later. Well, I usually send attachments or references in advance to let them read that before coming on meetingHello, Yangha! After reviewing what you said, I think we can make some parts clearer. The first sentence is perfect! "They were discussing product lines." It's a very natural and accurate expression. Let's look at the part "Our company's strength is high quality and power optimizer" in the second sentence. If you change "power optimizer" to "power optimization." it will sound more natural. "Our company's strength is high quality and power optimization." It would be better to say it like this, right? In the third sentence, it's more natural to use "inventory" instead of "inventories." "We have a lot of inventory in our warehouse." It would be much better to change it like this, right? You said the fourth sentence is "I might postpone the important item until later." It would be better to say it more naturally as "I might postpone the important item for later." In the last sentence, you said "If I am the first one to propose item I am afraid that others might things it is not important." You should use "think" instead of "things." And overall, it would be more natural to say "If I am the first one to propose the item, I am afraid that others might think it is not important." Yangha, after reviewing what you said today, I see that your English skills have improved a lot. If you practice a little more, you'll be able to speak English more fluently. Keep working hard in the future!
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 15. Agreeing and Disagreeing
item.description: cut the budget demographic make up customer base In light of our current budget issues, we need to think about our options. I like your idea of investing in social media advertisement, but Iâ€™m not sure I agree with decreasing our newspaper and TV ad costs. Itâ€™s true that social media is a highly effective way to market, but donâ€™t you think that we have to think about the older demographic as well? Q. Express your opinion to your coworkers. Say you disagree and explain why.A. Given our expanding business in China, I appreciate your suggestion to open an office in Beijing. However, Iâ€™m not entirely convinced about partnering with a local company. Donâ€™t you think our presence in China is already strong enough? We also have many fluent Chinese speakers within our team, so a local partnership might not be necessary. Instead, we should focus on building strong relationships with key figures in the Chinese Communist Party.Q. Have you ever disagreed with your companyâ€™s business strategy? If so, in what ways, and why?A. I wouldnâ€™t say I disagree with my companyâ€™s business strategy, but I often find myself at odds with people who prioritize their personal preferences over the bigger picture. In meetings, even when I prefer to stay quiet, I often feel compelled to voice my opinion that our product needs to be as perfect as possible. Business is like survival in a jungleâ€”no, itâ€™s even more complex than that. In business, the victim often doesnâ€™t realize theyâ€™ve been swallowed by a giant predator until itâ€™s too late.Q. Have you ever had a disagreement with a client? If so, why and how was it resolved?A. Situations like that can happen at any time. It might be related to design, functionality, or even user experience. While I donâ€™t typically communicate with clients since my teamâ€™s work isnâ€™t focused on customer care, if I do receive a customer complaint, I always strive to provide the best possible solution. First, I explain the reason behind the issue, and then I work on offering a reasonable solution that satisfies both sides. If thatâ€™s not possible, I usually propose an option that favors the client.Hello, Yangha! Looking at the sentences you mentioned, I think a few small changes could make them sound more natural and clear. In the first sentence, "We still invest money on that.", it would be more natural to use "in" instead of "on". "We still invest money "in" that." sounds much smoother. In the second sentence, "I feel much on this sentence.", using an expression like "strongly" instead of "much" would make it more natural. "I feel "strongly" about this sentence." In the third sentence, "I will loss my job but i don't feel afraid on that.", using "lose" instead of "loss", and "about that" instead of "on that" would make it more natural. "I will "lose" my job but I don't feel afraid "about" that." In the fourth sentence, "My co-worker suggested to get a partnership to a local company.", using "to partner with" instead of "to get a partnership" would make it more natural. "My co-worker suggested "to partner with" a local company." In the last sentence, "We have many fluent Chinese speaker at our company.", you need to add "s" to "speaker" to make it plural. "We have many fluent Chinese "speakers" at our company." You're doing really well, and I can see you're improving bit by bit. Keep up the good work!
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 14. Making Suggestions
item.description: benefits program take a survey high-end consumer I was looking into ways to improve our membership card. While the initial idea to let everyone receive the same benefits is a good one, I think that it might be better to focus on one specific target group. Why donâ€™t we first take a survey of our competitorsâ€™ high-end consumer rewards programs? Q. Make a suggestion to your team at the meeting. Explain your reasoning in detail.A. Iâ€™ve been looking into ways to increase insurance sales and have a suggestion. a â€œReferral programâ€. It doesnâ€™t simply means that giving temporary discounts to people who refer their friends. Weâ€™ll give special discounts on their monthly insurance payment. That would help build long-term loyalty, rather than just giving short-term perks.Q. At team meetings, do you consider yourself shy or do you speak up and make suggestions about ways to improve projects?A. I have a lot of ideas, and I want to achieve something meaningful in both my current projects and my career. I want to gain more experience, even if it sometimes leads to failure. I always tell myself, â€œOne success is enough to change my life.â€ I might face challenges and fail, but as long as I donâ€™t give up, Iâ€™ll grow stronger and eventually reach the top. Thatâ€™s why I always share my opinions, even when others stay quiet. I understand they might be afraid of failing, but Iâ€™m willing to take the risk.Q. What types of suggestions would you make to the way in which your team operates?A. I would suggest getting rid of outdated customs that are no longer necessary. While we can improve our work by adopting better approaches, we can also make progress by reducing waste in our processes. This doesnâ€™t mean I disregard the traditions we have; I believe there is valuable wisdom in them, and I aim to learn from that to create a better future. At the same time, I understand the importance of maintaining a relaxed work atmosphere because it helps people perform better. Iâ€™m not overly focused on efficiency alone, but itâ€™s important to remember that a companyâ€™s primary goal is to make moneyâ€”thatâ€™s the reason it exists. Thatâ€™s why I prioritize efficiency above all else.Q. What would you improve about employee benefits at your company?A. I want to create a culture that people are excited to be a part of. In our workplace, we should share ideas openly, regardless of our position, and discuss ways to improve both our work environment and our lives. If we can make our work genuinely engaging and meaningful, the concept of â€œwork-life balanceâ€ might not even feel necessary. I enjoy what I do, and I want others to feel the same wayâ€”instead of quietly complaining about the company. We have the power to change our circumstances, and I want everyone to realize that and be part of that change. Hello, Ha Yang! Looking at the sentences you mentioned, I think a few minor edits can make them sound more natural and clear. The first sentence, "They discuss strategy on increasing insurance sales." is almost perfect, but using "for"instead of "on" would make it more natural. "They discuss strategy for increasing insurance sales"sounds better, right? It's a great sentence! The second sentence, "I suggest referral program." can be improved by adding "a" before "referral program." "I suggest a referral program" sounds much more natural. The third sentence, "Many people just want money." is correct, but how about using a more varied expression? "Many people are simply motivated by money" would be a richer and more natural expression. You're doing really well! With small adjustments, you'll develop perfect English skills. I made a lot of mistakes today that I noticed while speaking. If I want to improve my English, I need to put myself in situations where I can speak it more often. I live in Nonsan, and I could use the excuse that there arenâ€™t many opportunities to speak English here. But thatâ€™s just an excuse. I shouldnâ€™t blame my environmentâ€”if I donâ€™t like it, I know itâ€™s up to me to change it.
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 13. Running a meeting
item.description: hang time out touch base Then we can figure out what we can do to fix the issue. How can we figure out the answer to this question without any help? That is the reason why I called this meeting. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining on short notice. We have an urgent matter to discuss today regarding the faulty design of our reclining chair, which has unfortunately caused injuries to a few customers. This is a serious issue, and our priority is to ensure customer safety while protecting our brand reputation. Letâ€™s focus on identifying the problem, finding immediate solutions, and setting a timeline for resolution. Before we start, letâ€™s quickly go over the agenda for todayâ€™s meeting: Review the reported design issue and customer feedback. Brainstorm potential immediate fixes and long-term solutions. Discuss communication with affected customers. Assign action items and propose a follow-up meeting to review progress. Does anyone have additional points to add before we dive in? Q. How often do you have team meetings? What types of issues are usually discussed at those meetings?A. We hold regular meetings three times a weekâ€”on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridaysâ€”where we primarily discuss issues related to the production line. Our focus is on manufacturing battery cells and BESS, and weâ€™re always vigilant about preventing defects.Q. Have you had meetings with foreigners? If so, what types of issues have you had communicating?A. Our headquarters is in Israel, so the team there has a distinctive accent. As you know, we Koreans typically donâ€™t have a noticeable accent, which sometimes makes communication challenging at first. However, once I get used to someoneâ€™s accent and pronunciation, itâ€™s no longer an issue. Time takes care of everything.Q. How do you like to run your meetings? Formally? Informally? Who sets the agenda and how strictly do you stick to it?A. I usually hold meetings in a formal manner. I set the agenda in advance and share it with the attendees beforehand. I don't like wasting time in meetings, so I strive to keep them short and focused. To achieve this, I make sure to stick closely to the agenda.Hello, Yangha! The sentence you said is really great! "It will be hold on Friday at 2:00 p.m. for status update." Using "held" instead of "hold" in this sentence would be more natural. "Be held" means "be held." while "hold" means "have." "It will be held on Friday at 2:00 p.m. for status update." This correction makes it sound more accurate and smooth! Yangha, you will become more perfect as you continue to practice! You are making great progress!>)
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 12. Review - Socializing
item.description: Our core business focuses on the development, production and marketing of a broad range of pharmaceutical drugs. Letâ€™s grab dinner sometime and catch up properly. Iâ€™m afraid that I wonâ€™t be able to next week. Q. Have you attended any high school or college reunions? How was the experience? What did you discuss with your former classmates? Did you share any fun stories or hear of any? A. I dropped out of high school in my first year, and similarly, I also left college in my freshman year. After that, I attended two colleges in Australia, but now that Iâ€™m in Korea, itâ€™s hard to meet the friends I made back then. I donâ€™t keep in touch with anyone. Maybe Iâ€™m not someone who keeps a wide circle of connections.Q. Do you keep in touch with former colleagues? How often do you meet them? What do you talk about?A. I meet up with my former colleagues about once every few months. We usually drink together until we get wasted. And thatâ€™s all we do, Korean old menâ€™s style. Of course, we have some conversation while drinking. Our topics are commonly works or trivial things weâ€™ve done like as before.Q. What was the last conference or business-networking event that you attended? Did you meet any foreigners? If so, what did you discuss?A. I attended Microsoftâ€™s AI Tour event about six months ago. I met a lot of people there, but we didnâ€™t really have any in-depth discussions. I mostly just listened to the conference and joined in on the activities they had prepared. I went by myself, unlike many others who came with their colleagues as a team. Anyway, there were so many people from all around the world. But I wasnâ€™t quite brave enough to approach them and start a conversation. It felt like I was the only one there on my own.Hello, Yangha! With just a few small changes, you can express yourself even more clearly. The first sentence is almost perfect! Instead of "I'll call you back in the next week." it would be more natural to say "I'll call you back next week." In the second sentence, instead of "Are you available on that time?", it should be "Are you available at that time?". It's more natural to use "at" instead of "on." In the last sentence, instead of "Where you stay?", it should be "Where do you stay?". After "Where." you need to add "do" and before "stay"you need to add "you" to make a complete sentence. Yangha, your English skills have improved so much! If you keep working hard, you'll become even more perfect!
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 11. Telling a story
item.description: get stuck in traffic Too bad it was for a business trip. I took a gamble thinking that if I took a taxi, I could make it to Grand Central on time. I think Iâ€™d better take the subway. Q. What is the funniest story you have ever heard from a colleague? What was it about?A. It was Halloween recently. One of my friend was asked to attend a Halloween party in Seoul. And He was heard that the dress code is â€œblackâ€. So he decided to wear black tights to make some fun. He thought other people may wear some kind of costume which fit for Halloween. And the day that the party held, he found that it wasnâ€™t a party he expected. He saw everyoneâ€™s in black suit. I donâ€™t know what happened the next, but my friend showed me a picture he took at that party. It was so weird, he stood around the people whoâ€™s in formal suits. â†’ It was Halloween recently, and one of my friends was invited to a Halloween party in Seoul. He was told that the dress code was â€œblack,â€ so, hoping to add a bit of fun, he decided to wear black tights, thinking everyone would show up in Halloween costumes. But when he arrived at the party, it wasnâ€™t quite what heâ€™d expected. He looked around and realized everyone else was dressed in formal black suits. Iâ€™m not sure what happened next, but he showed me a picture from that nightâ€”it was hilarious! There he was, standing in a crowd of people in business attire, completely out of place in his costume. Q. Have you had any interesting situations that occurred while traveling for business? What happened?A. I donâ€™t have any. (kill joy)Q. At lunch, what do you discuss with your coworkers?A. We talked about the business documents of our company which address rules, procedures, and standards of our works. We all know that documents are not good enough, so we discuss how to make it better but we found that itâ€™s really hard to change others, not us. And our roles are not making that kind of docs. So we ended up the talk saying our discussion will goes for nothing. â†’ We talked about our companyâ€™s business documents that outline the rules, procedures, and standards for our work. We all agreed that these documents arenâ€™t quite up to par, so we discussed ways to improve them. But we realized itâ€™s tough to bring about change when it involves others, not just ourselves. Besides, creating these documents isnâ€™t actually our responsibility. In the end, we wrapped up the conversation, admitting that our discussion probably wouldnâ€™t lead to much. Hello, Park Yangha/David! Looking at the sentences you mentioned, I see that a few small adjustments could make them even more natural English sentences! In the first sentence, "It take me to two hours to get the hotel." you should change "It take" to "It takes.""It takes" means "it takes time," while "take" means "to take up time," so it was used incorrectly. "to" indicates a "destination," so changing it to "get to the hotel" would be more natural. In the second sentence, "There are so many bike driver." you should change it to "There are so many bike drivers." "driver" means "driver," and the plural form is "drivers." The third sentence, "Maybe in the next year, I will go to Bohol." is well written, but it could also be written as "Maybe next year, I will go to Bohol." It's a simpler way to express it. In the fourth sentence, "Bohol is one of the best spot for scuba diving." you should change it to "Bohol is one of the best spots for scuba diving." "spot" means "place," and the plural form is "spots." In the last sentence, "The taxi driver was waiting to me." you should change it to "The taxi driver was waiting for me." "waiting for" means "waiting," so using "for" instead of "to" would be more natural. Good job, David! Keep practicing and you'll be able to write perfect English sentences. Iâ€™m able to recognize my mistakes when I speak in English, I still omit â€œsâ€, use singular form very often. I understand how to use â€œsâ€ in a proper way but it seems hard to get used to it. I want to count how many days will it take. As long as I achieve that, nothing matters.I can recognize my mistakes when I speak English, but I still often omit the â€˜sâ€™ and use singular forms. I understand the correct way to use â€˜s,â€™ but itâ€™s hard to get used to. I want to track how many days it will take to improve. As long as I achieve this, nothing else matters.
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 10. Progress Update
item.description: go over last minute worst-case scenario over the phone Iâ€™m afraid that I wonâ€™t be able to next week. I am booked solid with meetings and presentations for the next week or so. Q. Have you ever had issues with trying to meet with someone because of scheduling conflicts? How did you resolve those situations?A. I rarely encounter scheduling conflicts when it comes to business, but sometimes itâ€™s challenging to meet my friends at a time when we can all get together. Unlike me, most of my friends are married, so they have their own families and need to take care of their children as well. This simply means that I have to adjust my schedule to fit theirs, but thatâ€™s no problem as long as we get to meet.Q. What type of software do you use to keep track of your meetings? Why?A. I use several Microsoft applications to manage my schedule and meetings, especially Teams, Planner, and Outlook. Our company provides licenses for these tools, and theyâ€™re quite effective for organizing my time and tasks. That said, I prefer Google Calendar for my personal life. With Google Assistant, I can easily add events by voiceâ€”like saying, â€˜Hey Google, schedule a doctorâ€™s appointment for this Saturday at 9 amâ€™ It then reminds me when the time comes.Q. If an urgent issue came up and you had to reschedule a meeting, how would you handle the problem?A. Iâ€™ll inform the attendees as soon as possible and try to reschedule the meeting after addressing the urgent issue. If theyâ€™re unavailable at the new time, the meeting isnâ€™t the only optionâ€”we can still discuss via email or chat. Another good option is holding a Zoom meeting. I typically have online meetings rather than in-person ones, as my company is international.Hello, Yangha! Looking at the sentences you wrote, I think a few adjustments would make them sound more natural in English. The first sentence, "I have only little vacation time." is almost perfect, but using "a little" instead of "little" would sound more natural. Saying "I have only "a little" vacation time." makes it clearer that you have "little vacation time." The second sentence, "He always yell" would be more accurate with the addition of an "s" to the verb "yell." Saying "He always "yells"." means "He always shouts." The third sentence, "I bumped into my old friend who graduate from same elementary school." needs to change "graduate" to past tense. Saying "I bumped into my old friend who "graduated" from the same elementary school." makes it clearer that you "bumped into an old friend who graduated from the same elementary school." The fourth sentence, "I was a bit discomfortable." needs "discomfortable" changed to "uncomfortable." Saying "I was a bit "uncomfortable"." means "I was a bit uncomfortable." The last sentence, "It is kind of waste of time." would be more accurate with an "a" before "waste." Saying "It is kind of "a" waste of time." means "It is kind of a waste of time." Yangha, it's great to see you working hard on your English studies! With a little effort, you'll be able to speak English more naturally and accurately. I'm cheering for you! I have to adjust my schedule to fit theirs. â†’ I have to adjust my schedule to fit theirs. Our company provide tool to organize our schedule. â†’ Our company provides tools to organize our schedule. I am just tried to be honest. â†’ I I am just trying to be honest. I will set priority of them. â†’ I will set them as a priority. The organizer give me time. â†’ The organizer gives me time. Itâ€™s my bad habit to omit â€œsâ€ after verbs and nouns even though when I do know how to use it. The practice makes perfect. What I have to is only practice. Iâ€™m thinking how to make the environment around me changed for that practice.Itâ€™s a bad habit of mine to omit the â€˜sâ€™ after verbs and nouns, even though I know how to use it. Practice makes perfectâ€”what I need is simply more practice. Iâ€™m considering how to create an environment that helps me build this habit.
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 9. Catching up with Others
item.description: hectic extension: ë‚´ì„ ë²ˆí˜¸ show someone around Iâ€™ve been here for about three years, going on four this July. Welcome aboard. Letâ€™s grab dinner sometime and catch up properly. Hello, Yangha! Looking at the sentences you wrote, I think a few adjustments would make them sound more natural in English. The first sentence, "I have only little vacation time." is almost perfect, but using "a little" instead of "little" would sound more natural. Saying "I have only "a little" vacation time." makes it clearer that you have "little vacation time." The second sentence, "He always yell" would be more accurate with the addition of an "s" to the verb "yell." Saying "He always "yells"." means "He always shouts." The third sentence, "I bumped into my old friend who graduate from same elementary school." needs to change "graduate" to past tense. Saying "I bumped into my old friend who "graduated" from the same elementary school." makes it clearer that you "bumped into an old friend who graduated from the same elementary school." The fourth sentence, "I was a bit discomfortable." needs "discomfortable" changed to "uncomfortable." Saying "I was a bit "uncomfortable"." means "I was a bit uncomfortable." The last sentence, "It is kind of waste of time." would be more accurate with an "a" before "waste." Saying "It is kind of "a" waste of time." means "It is kind of a waste of time." Yangha, it's great to see you working hard on your English studies! With a little effort, you'll be able to speak English more naturally and accurately. I'm cheering for you!
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 8. Introducing your company
item.description: pharmaceutical drug domestic market expand overseas potential growth total revenue final phase higly competitive Our core business focuses on the development, production and marketing of a broad range of pharmaceutical drugs. Weâ€™re a major player in the domestic market, with limited presence in the global market. We have a few drugs in the pipeline that are in the final phases of development. Hello, Yangha! These are good sentences! With a few small adjustments, you can speak even more naturally and clearly. The first sentence, "Our property is in Korea country." is almost perfect, but it would be more natural to say "South Korea" instead of "Korea country." "Korea" already means a country, so adding "country" can sound a little awkward. So, saying "Our property is in South Korea." would sound more natural! In the second sentence, "Our business to make renewable energy accessible." you should change "to make" to "is to make." Saying "Our business is to make renewable energy accessible." would sound cleaner! In the last sentence, "Our stock market has been dropped." it would be more natural to use "declined" or "fallen" instead of "dropped." "dropped" gives a feeling of suddenly falling, while "declined" or "fallen" expresses a gradual fall. So, saying "Our stock market has been declining." or "Our stock market has fallen." would sound more natural! Overall, you are doing really well! With just a few small adjustments, you can make your sentences perfect. If you keep practicing, you will be able to speak English more naturally.
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 7. Meeting People for the First Time
item.description: be in for a treat in charge of based in Iâ€™m sorry. Aloow me to introduce myself. I work at the Korean company FastTradingCo as a Technology Advisor. Pleased to meet you Hello, Yangha! If you make a few changes, your English sentences will sound more natural! In the first sentence, you should change "There is long waits" to "There are long waits." "Waits" is plural, so you need to use "are." "Between presentations" is fine. So, "There are long waits between presentations, but the topics are interesting." is perfect! The second sentence should be changed to "Mary works at BestMobileCo as a software developer." You need to change "work" to "works" to make it consistent with the present tense! The third sentence should be changed to "If you are interested in art, I would like to recommend Seoul National Museum to you." You should use "interested in" instead of "interesting" and "would like to recommend" instead of "like to recommend." Adding "to you" makes it even better! The fourth sentence is almost perfect, but it would be more natural to say "They provide us with free meals" instead of "They give us free meals." Using "provide" instead of "give" and adding "with" makes it even better! In the last fifth sentence, you should change "I gave them sometime to finished their work correctly" to "I gave them some time to finish their work correctly." You need to use "some time" instead of "sometime" and "finish" instead of "finished" to make the tense consistent with "gave." Yangha, you are amazing for always trying to learn new things! With a little more practice, your English skills will improve even more!
item.guid: Studies/English/SPICUS (24.10~24.11)/Unit 7. Meeting People for the First Time.md
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 6. Review - Working on Projects
item.description: Hello, Yangha! I'll tell you how to make the sentences you mentioned sound more natural. The first sentence, "I experience typhoon too." would sound more natural as "I experienced a typhoon too." "Experience" is a verb that means to have something happen to you, so when you're talking about something that happened in the past, you need to use the past tense, "experienced." And "typhoon" is a natural phenomenon, so it's good to put "a" in front of it. The second sentence, "We will have a global meeting next next week." can be simplified to "We will have a global meeting next week." "Next next week" is a common expression in Korean, but in English, "next week" is enough to convey the meaning. The third sentence, "I think I had a lot of issues with outsourcing." is excellent! This sentence is perfect. The fourth sentence, "Some of our sub-constructors provided with some effects." would sound more natural as "Some of our sub-constructors provided some effects." Using "provided" instead of "provided with" makes the sentence more concise and natural. The last sentence, "We tried to figure out what is the real reason for the bad product." can be changed to "We tried to figure out the real reason for the bad product." Omitting "what is" makes the sentence more concise and natural. Your English skills have really improved! With a little more practice, you'll be able to communicate perfectly in English. Keep it up!
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 5. Reporting Success
item.description: beta testing functionality user-friendly integrated intradepartmental So far, the feedback has been positive. There are a few things we need to iron out. Weâ€™ll contact each of your departments to get the ball rolling on fixing these problems. Hello, Yangha! I see some areas where you can make your sentences sound more natural. With a few small changes, you can make your writing clearer and more concise. First sentence, "They don't have interest in my project." Instead of "interest." you can use "interested"for a more natural expression. "They are not interested in my project" would be better. Second sentence, "It is too spicy for them to general people." Instead of "general people." "the general public" is a more familiar expression, and instead of "for,"using "for them to be" makes the sentence smoother. How about changing it to "It is too spicy for them to be comfortable with."? Third sentence "We need to minimize the spicy taste."is great! You're doing well. Fourth sentence, "They think computer do everything."Instead of "computer do." using "computers can do"makes the sentence more natural. Try changing it to "They think computers can do everything." Last sentence, "It is always hard to address issue to them." Using "address issues with them" instead of "address issue to them" is more natural, and changing "it is always hard" to "it's always difficult" makes it look cleaner. How about changing it to "It's always difficult to address issues with them."? Yangha, it's great to see your continuous efforts! With a little more practice, you'll become a perfect English speaker! Fighting!
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 4. Oursourcing
item.description: scope of work keep on track with go live request for proposal(RFP) be in good hands Letâ€™s review the statement of work to confirm points so that weâ€™re all on the same page. This project is urgent, so we need a quick turnaround on setting up our website. Would you be able to finish ahead of schedule? Hello, Yangha! After reviewing the sentences you mentioned, I think they can be made even more natural with a few minor corrections! In the first sentence, "There not too many changes.", you need to add "are" after "There" to make it a complete sentence. "There are not too many changes." sounds much more natural. The second sentence, "They are not just useful but also necessary.", is perfectly correct! You did a great job! In the third sentence, "Database should be no malfunction.", it's more natural to use "malfunction-free" instead of "no malfunction". "Database should be malfunction-free." sounds smoother. In the fourth sentence, "Our expectations for database shouldn't be too different.", it's better to add "the" before "database". "Our expectations for the database shouldn't be too different." conveys the meaning more accurately. In the fifth sentence, "We have many contractors because we are manufacturing company.", it's better to change "manufacturing company" to "a manufacturing company". "We have many contractors because we are a manufacturing company." makes for a more natural sentence. Yangha, with just a few grammatical tweaks, these are really great English sentences! Keep practicing and your skills will definitely improve! There not too many changes. â†’ There arenâ€™t too many changes. They are not just useful but also necessary. â†’ Theyâ€™re not just useful but also essential. Database should be no malfunction. â†’ The database should be free of malfunctions. Our expectations for database shouldnâ€™t be too different. â†’ Our expectations for the database shouldnâ€™t differ too much. We have many contractors because we are manufacturing company. â†’ We have many contractors because weâ€™re a manufacturing company.
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 3. Explaining Project Setbacks
item.description: IPO(Initial Public Offering) at this point It seems like weâ€™re going to have to push back the deadline. The problem is that we donâ€™t have much wiggle room with the deadline. Itâ€™s best to have this project finished on time, no matter the cost. The sentences you said today are almost perfect! However, with a few minor adjustments, they can become even clearer and more natural English sentences. The first sentence, â€œDue to bad weather in contractorâ€™s country, the deadline will be delayed.â€ is really well said! If you write â€œthe contractorâ€ instead of â€œcontractorâ€™sâ€, it will be even more perfect. Adding â€œtheâ€ makes it clear that â€œcontractorâ€™sâ€ refers to a specific contractor. The second sentence, â€œI think to that work for 2 days only.â€ sounds a bit awkward. â€œIâ€™ll workâ€ is a more natural expression than â€œI think to that workâ€. â€œIâ€™ll work for 2 days onlyâ€ is a complete sentence. The third sentence, â€œSome people doesnâ€™t meet the requirement for work.â€ should be â€œdonâ€™tâ€ instead of â€œdoesnâ€™tâ€. The fourth sentence, â€œI am still thinking about how should I do?â€ should be â€œtoâ€ instead of â€œshouldâ€. â€œI am still thinking about how to do?â€ sounds more natural. The last sentence, â€œIt very complicated.â€ should be â€œItâ€™s very complicated.â€ English sentences need a subject and a verb to be complete sentences. Youâ€™re doing really well! You seem to be very good at English, Yangha. Keep practicing and you will be able to develop even more fluent English skills.
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Markdown Syntax
item.description:
To create a heading, add number signs (#) in front of a word or phrase. The number of number signs you use should correspond to the heading level. For example, to create a heading level three (<h3>), use three number signs (e.g., ### My Header).Alternatively, on the line below the text, add any number of == characters for heading level 1 or -- characters for heading level 2.Dataview (inline field '='): Error: -- PARSING FAILED -------------------------------------------------- > 1 | = | ^ Expected one of the following: '(', 'null', boolean, date, duration, file link, list ('[1, 2, 3]'), negated field, number, object ('{ a: 1, b: 2 }'), string, variable Markdown applications donâ€™t agree on how to handle a missing space between the number signs (#) and the heading name. For compatibility, always put a space between the number signs and the heading name.You should also put blank lines before and after a heading for compatibility.To create paragraphs, use a blank line to separate one or more lines of text.Unless the paragraph is in a list, donâ€™t indent paragraphs with spaces or tabs.
 Note: If you need to indent paragraphs in the output, see the section on how to indent (tab).To create a line break or new line (<br>), end a line with two or more spaces, and then type return.
You can use two or more spaces (commonly referred to as â€œtrailing whitespaceâ€) for line breaks in nearly every Markdown application, but itâ€™s controversial. Itâ€™s hard to see trailing whitespace in an editor, and many people accidentally or intentionally put two spaces after every sentence. For this reason, you may want to use something other than trailing whitespace for line breaks. If your Markdown application supports HTML, you can use the <br> HTML tag.For compatibility, use trailing white space or the <br> HTML tag at the end of the line.There are two other options I donâ€™t recommend using. CommonMark and a few other lightweight markup languages let you type a backslash (\) at the end of the line, but not all Markdown applications support this, so it isnâ€™t a great option from a compatibility perspective. And at least a couple lightweight markup languages donâ€™t require anything at the end of the line â€” just type return and theyâ€™ll create a line break.You can add emphasis by making text bold or italic.To bold text, add two asterisks or underscores before and after a word or phrase. To bold the middle of a word for emphasis, add two asterisks without spaces around the letters.Markdown applications donâ€™t agree on how to handle underscores in the middle of a word. For compatibility, use asterisks to bold the middle of a word for emphasis.To italicize text, add one asterisk or underscore before and after a word or phrase. To italicize the middle of a word for emphasis, add one asterisk without spaces around the letters.Markdown applications donâ€™t agree on how to handle underscores in the middle of a word. For compatibility, use asterisks to italicize the middle of a word for emphasis.To emphasize text with bold and italics at the same time, add three asterisks or underscores before and after a word or phrase. To bold and italicize the middle of a word for emphasis, add three asterisks without spaces around the letters. Note: The order of the em and strong tags might be reversed depending on the Markdown processor you're using.Markdown applications donâ€™t agree on how to handle underscores in the middle of a word. For compatibility, use asterisks to bold and italicize the middle of a word for emphasis.To create a blockquote, add a > in front of a paragraph.> Dorothy followed her through many of the beautiful rooms in her castle.

item.title: EventListnerOption
item.description:
last updated : 2024-07-31Passive event listeners are a new feature in the DOM spec that enable developers to opt-in to better scroll performance by eliminating the need for scrolling to block on touch and wheel event listeners. Developers can annotate touch and wheel listeners with {passive: true} to indicate that they will never invoke preventDefault. This feature shipped in Chrome 51, Firefox 49 and landed in WebKit. Check out the video below for a side-by-side of passive event listeners in action:
demo videoSmooth scrolling performance is essential to a good experience on the web, especially on touch-based devices. All modern browsers have a threaded scrolling feature to permit scrolling to run smoothly even when expensive JavaScript is running, but this optimization is partially defeated by the need to wait for the results of
any touchstart and touchmove handlers, which may prevent the scroll entirely by calling preventDefault() on the event. While there are particular scenarios where an author may indeed want to prevent scrolling, analysis indicates that the majority of touch event handlers on the web never actually call preventDefault(), so browsers often block scrolling unnecessarily. For instance, in Chrome for Android 80% of the touch events that block scrolling never actually prevent it. 10% of these events add more than 100ms of delay to the start of scrolling, and a catastrophic delay of at least 500ms occurs in 1% of scrolls.
Many developers are surprised to learn that simply adding an empty touch handler to their document can have a
significant negative impact on scroll performance. Developers quite reasonably expect that the act of observing an event should not have any side-effects.
The fundamental problem here is not limited to touch events. eventswheel
suffer from an identical issue. In contrast, pointer event handlers are designed to never delay scrolling (though developers can declaratively suppress scrolling altogether with the touch-action CSS property), so do not suffer from this issue. Essentially the passive event listener proposal brings the performance properties of pointer events to touch and wheel events.
This proposal provides a way for authors to indicate at handler registration time whether the handler may call preventDefault() on the event (i.e. whether it needs an event that is cancelable). When no touch or wheel handlers at a particular point require a cancelable event, a user agent is free to start scrolling immediately without waiting for JavaScript. That is, passive listeners are free from surprising performance side-effects.First, we need a mechanism for attaching additional information to an event listener. Today the capture argument to addEventListener is the closest example of something like this, but its usage is pretty opaque: document.addEventListener('touchstart', handler, true);
EventListenerOptions lets us write this more explicitly as: document.addEventListener('touchstart', handler, {capture: true});
This is simply the new (extensible) syntax for existing behavior - specifying whether you want the listener invoked during the capture phase or bubbling phase.Now that we have an extensible syntax for specifying options at event handler registration time, we can add a new passive option which declares up-front that the listener will never call preventDefault() on the event. If it does, the user agent will just ignore the request (ideally generating at least a console warning), as it already does for events with Event.cancelable=false. A developer can verify this by querying Event.defaultPrevented before and after calling preventDefault(). Eg: addEventListener(document, "touchstart", function(e) { console.log(e.defaultPrevented); // will be false e.preventDefault(); // does nothing since the listener is passive console.log(e.defaultPrevented); // still false }, Modernizr.passiveeventlisteners ? {passive: true} : false);
Now rather than having to block scrolling whenever there are any touch or wheel listener, the browser only needs to do this when there are non-passive listeners (see TouchEvents spec). passive listeners are free of performance side-effects.By marking a touch or wheel listener as passive, the developer is promising the handler won't call preventDefault to disable scrolling. This frees the browser up to respond to scrolling immediately without waiting for JavaScript, thus ensuring a reliably smooth scrolling experience for the user.
Because older browsers will interpret any object in the 3rd argument as a true value for the capture argument, it's important for developers to use feature detection or a polyfill when using this API, to avoid unforeseen results. Feature detection for specific options can be done as follows:// Test via a getter in the options object to see if the passive property is accessed var supportsPassive = false; try { var opts = Object.defineProperty({}, 'passive', { get: function() { supportsPassive = true; } }); window.addEventListener("testPassive", null, opts); window.removeEventListener("testPassive", null, opts); } catch (e) {} // Use our detect's results. passive applied if supported, capture will be false either way. elem.addEventListener('touchstart', fn, supportsPassive ? { passive: true } : false);
To make this simpler you can use the feature detect from Detect It, eg: elem.addEventListener('touchstart', fn, detectIt.passiveEvents ? {passive:true} : false);
Modernizr also has a detect here. There is an open standards debate around providing a simpler API for dictionary member feature detection.There are scenarios where an author may intentionally want to consistently disable scrolling by cancelling all touch or wheel events. These include: Panning and zooming a map Full-page/full-screen games In these cases, the current behavior (which prevents scrolling optimization) is perfectly adequate, since scrolling itself is being prevented consistently. There is no need to use passive listeners in these cases, though it's often still a good idea to apply a touch-action: none CSS rule to make your intention explicit (eg. supporting browsers with Pointer Events but not Touch Events). However, in a number of common scenarios events don't need to block scrolling - for instance: User activity monitoring which just wants to know when the user was last active touchstart handlers that hide some active UI (like tooltips) touchstart and touchend handlers that style UI elements (without suppressing the click event). For these scenarios, the passive option can be added (with appropriate feature detection) without any other code changes, resulting in a significantly smoother scrolling experience.There are a few more complicated scenarios where the handler only wants to suppress scrolling under certain conditions, such as: Swiping horizontally to rotate a carousel, dismiss an item or reveal a drawer, while still permitting vertical scrolling.
In this case, use touch-action: pan-y to declaratively disable scrolling that starts along the horizontal axis without having to call preventDefault() (test page). To continue to work correctly in all browsers, calls to preventDefault should be conditional on the lack of support for the particular touch-action rule being used (note that Safari 9 currently only supports touch-action: manipulation). A UI element (like YouTube's volume slider) which slides on horizontal wheel events without changing the scrolling behavior on vertical wheel events. Since there is no equivalent of "touch-action" for wheel events, this case can only be implemented with non-passive wheel listeners. Event delegation patterns where the code that adds the listener won't know if the consumer will cancel the event. One option here is to do delegation separately for passive and non-passive listeners (as if they were different event types entirely).
It's also possible to leverage touch-action as above (treating Touch Events as you would Pointer Events.
You can get a quick idea of the benefit possible (and potential breakage) by forcing touch/wheel listeners to be treated as passive via chrome://flags/#passive-listener-default (new in Chrome 52). This makes it easy to do your own side-by-side comparisons like this popular video.
See this video for tips on how to use Chrome's Developer Tools to identify listeners that are blocking scrolling. You can monitor event timestamps to measure scroll jank in the wild, and use Chromium's tracing system to look at the InputLatency records for scrolling when debugging.
The Chrome team is working on a proposal for both a PerformanceTimeline API and more DevTools features to help web developers get better visibility into this problem today.

item.title: 170615 - Animal Test
item.description: Animal testing often causes heated debates and protests. The most controversial animal testing is the test that particularly includes testing of medicines for research and biological reproduction. As much as animal testing is controversial, there are justifiable reasons supporting animal testing. Of course, clinical trials are not only negatives. in the manufacturing of drugs that allows pharmaceutical companies to get drugs onto the marker safer and faster. For example, â€˜Pasteurâ€™s experimentsâ€™ produced vaccines for children, such as measles, which are dangerous for children because of inoculation of rabies. When it is turned out that only 1.16% of diseases are common to both human and animal, however, the controversy arose due to not only the ethics of animal testing but also its effectiveness. In 1957, â€˜Talido maideuâ€™ was the main ingredient of a medicine called â€˜Kontereuâ€™, produced by a German pharmaceutical company. The drug showed excellent efficacy with sedation or sleeping pills, especially when the pregnant women developed her pregnancy symptoms. There were numerous animal experiments that were conducted at the time of the drug, and then marketed at the time of being declared â€˜harmlessâ€™ in animal testing, but in 1962, there were tens of thousands of deformed babies and thousands of deaths worldwide. Later, many pharmaceutical companies experimented with mice, rabbits, and primates to simulate the side effects of â€˜tallidomaideuâ€™, but when injected with very high concentrations of 75 to 300 times of the drug was injected, particularly in the New Zealand white rabbit, which was able to reproduce its side effects. This shows inefficient side effects that could not only be seen in animals, but only humans. Secondly, it is unethical to confine an animalâ€™s life to a laboratory and to live a life of pain. Some experiments involve cruel drug experimentation such as drug abuse, strangulation, and others are subjected to cruel experiments. Euthanasia is also being carried out after animal testing. According to the U.S. Department of Agriculture (UDOA) in 2010, 97,123 animals suffered during the trial without anesthesia. Despite the fact that real animals and humans share only 1.16 percent of the population, we are committed to doing so. Lastly, there are new technologies that can replace animal testing because of advances in science. There are many different technologies, such as â€˜INVITOâ€™, which breeds and research cells in â€˜PETRIOâ€™ dishes, which are more efficient than animal tests because of human cells. They can also obtain blood samples obtained from humans and study blood samples, and also can be experimented with commercially available, such as â€˜EPIDEMâ€™ and â€˜THINCETâ€™. In addition, using computer simulations, one can conduct research without experiments on biology. In conclusion, we should be reminded that animal testing is wasteful inaccurate and unethical and scientists and pharmaceutical companies should looking at the new alternatives that are being developed before resorting to animal testing.

item.title: LYT's Epic Life Audit Template
item.description:
ë³¸ í…œí”Œë¦¿ì€ Linking Your Thinking with Nick Miloì˜ Youtubeì—ì„œ ì œê³µë©ë‹ˆë‹¤. ì˜ìƒ ë§í¬ Add a link up to your home note, or "personal retreat" note or "life compass" note or similar. This epic life audit is a powerful way to gain perspective on your life and realign your efforts to live with more meaning and intention. What you need. A private place. A thinking space. Prepare yourself beforehand. Ideally a few days prior, just start thinking loosely about where you are in life and how things are going. Budget 2-3 hours of private, uninterrupted time. Or 3 time blocks of 30-45 minutes. Result you'll say afterwards: I know exactly where I am, I know how I got here, and I know where I would like to go. Result you'll feel afterwards: Deeply knowing whatever it is you care about, and how you want to move forward. How to go through it: Don't score based on outcomes, but on alignment. From the bottom...up! Reasoning for Overall Score Two hours later, your final reflections will go here. Next actions and takeaways Try to give yourself 4-8 high-level actions and takeaways. Below is an example: Live a lifestyle with movement & vitality: Significantly change my current lifestyle from a sedentary one, back to one with movement and vitality. Reasoning for Overall Score After finishing the sections on Recreation, Environment, and Body, then roll up your takeaways into a paragraph here. Reasoning for Overall Score After finishing the subsections on Hobbies, Travel, Leisure, Consuming, and Experiences, then roll up your takeaways into a paragraph here. Hobbies: Current = x | Ideal = x Travel: Current = x | Ideal = x Leisure: Current = x | Ideal = x Consuming: Current = x | Ideal = x Experiences: Current = x | Ideal = x Reasoning for Overall Score After finishing the subsections on Physical Environment and Sensory Experience, then roll up your takeaways into a paragraph here. Physical Environment: Current = x | Ideal = x Sensory Experience: Current = x | Ideal = x Reasoning for Overall Score After finishing the subsections on Sleep, Nutrition, Movement, and Exercise, then roll up your takeaways into a paragraph here. Sleep: Current = x | Ideal = x Nutrition: Current = x | Ideal = x Movement: Current = x | Ideal = x Exercise: Current = x | Ideal = x Reasoning for Overall Score After finishing the sections on Soul, Partnership, Family and Friends, then roll up your takeaways into a paragraph here. Reasoning for Overall Score After finishing the subsections on Life Purpose and Spirituality, then roll up your takeaways into a paragraph here. Life Purpose & Personal Legend & Personal Discovery: Current = x | Ideal = x Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Tortor aliquam nulla facilisi cras fermentum odio eu feugiat pretium. Leo a diam sollicitudin tempor id eu nisl. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do. Spirituality: Current = x | Ideal = x Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua. Tortor aliquam nulla facilisi cras fermentum odio eu feugiat pretium. Leo a diam sollicitudin tempor id eu nisl. Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit, sed do. Reasoning for Overall Score After finishing the subsections on Intimacy & Closeness, Romance, and Fun & Lightness, then roll up your takeaways into a paragraph here. Intimacy & Closeness: Current = x | Ideal = x Romance: Current = x | Ideal = x Fun & Lightness: Current = x | Ideal = x Reasoning for Overall Score After finishing the subsections on Family Connection and Family Health, then roll up your takeaways into a paragraph here. Family Connection: Current = x | Ideal = x Family Health: Current = x | Ideal = x Reasoning for Overall Score After finishing the subsections on Close Friends, Old Friends, Community & Social Connections, and Friends that are Protemoi, then roll up your takeaways into a paragraph here. Close Friends: Current = x | Ideal = x Old Friends: Current = x | Ideal = x Community & Social Connections: Current = x | Ideal = x Friends that are Protemoi: Current = x | Ideal = x Reasoning for Overall Score After finishing the sections on Work, Finances and Mind, then roll up your takeaways into a paragraph here. Reasoning for Overall Score After finishing the subsections on Career/Business Health & Trajectory, Protemoi Relationships, Creation/Production, and Sense of Contribution, then roll up your takeaways into a paragraph here. Career/Business Health & Trajectory: Current = x | Ideal = x Protemoi Relationships: Current = x | Ideal = x Creation/Production: Current = x | Ideal = x Sense of Contribution: Current = x | Ideal = x Reasoning for Overall Score After finishing the subsections on Net Worth, Cash Flow, Sense of Control & Confidence, then roll up your takeaways into a paragraph here. Net Worth: Current = x | Ideal = x Cash Flow: Current = x | Ideal = x Sense of Control & Confidence: Current = x | Ideal = x Reasoning for Overall Score After finishing the subsections on Sense of Learning, Sense of Sensemaking, and Sense of Personal Growth, then roll up your takeaways into a paragraph here. Sense of Learning: Current = x | Ideal = x Sense of Sensemaking: Current = x | Ideal = x Sense of Personal Growth: Current = x | Ideal = x Be kind to yourself. Be kind by being honest with yourself. The hidden benefit to this exercise isn't the score, it's the hidden emotions and deeper understandings that bubble up. It's the clarity and confidence the exercise creates. Best of luck to you,
Nick If you want help setting up your own thinking space, learn more here.
