item.title: 2024-02-05 Questions from HQ
item.description: Question: Are the rack and container assembly instructions currently available in multiple languages, including Chinese, or do they require translation? Answer: The assembly instructions are currently only available in Korean. We recognize the importance of making these accessible to our team in China and plan to have them translated into English as an intermediary step. This process is expected to take approximately one week. We will explore options for translation into Chinese to ensure clarity and accessibility for all team members involved in the assembly process. Question: Do we have visual aids, such as videos, to supplement the assembly instructions? Answer: At the moment, we do not have video documentation of the assembly process. However, we acknowledge the value of visual aids in enhancing understanding and reducing the potential for errors. We will initiate the creation of video tutorials that detail the assembly process, ensuring that these resources are comprehensive and easy to follow. Question: What specific assembly procedures are currently undertaken by the Korean CM, and are we fully aware of these processes? Answer: The Korean CM handles a range of assembly procedures that are documented in our standard operating procedures. However, it's essential to conduct a thorough review to ensure that all processes are fully captured and up-to-date. We are in the process of auditing these procedures to confirm their completeness and accuracy. Question: Considering the assembly procedures performed by the Korean CM, do we believe it's feasible to replicate these processes in China without significant obstacles? Answer: Based on our initial assessment, we believe that transitioning these assembly processes to China is feasible. The procedures do not require specialized skills that cannot be replicated or taught in China. However, we must ensure that all procedural documentation is current, translated, and adapted as necessary to meet any local regulatory requirements or operational differences. Question: Are there any anticipated challenges or limitations in transferring the assembly line to China, such as differences in regulations, standards, or workforce skills? Answer: While we anticipate a smooth transition overall, we are mindful of potential challenges such as differences in regulatory standards, the need for workforce training, and the adaptation of procedures to local practices. We are committed to conducting a detailed analysis to identify any such challenges early in the process and develop strategies to address them effectively. Question: What will be the approach if there are questions raised during the meeting that cannot be immediately answered? Answer: Should any questions arise that I cannot answer directly, I will take detailed notes and follow up with my direct manager to ensure a timely and accurate response. We are committed to transparency and effective communication throughout this transition process. Question: Do we need to translate the assembly instructions? Are there videos? Answer: Yes, the instructions are only in Korean now. We need to translate them into English, which will take about a week. We don't have videos yet, but we plan to make them to help everyone understand the process better. Question: Can we use the same assembly procedures in China as in Korea? Answer: The procedures we use in Korea can be used in China too. We don't see big problems with moving the assembly there. Most tasks don't need special skills. But, we need to update and translate our instructions to make sure everyone can follow them. Question: What problems might we face moving to China? Answer: We might face some challenges, like different rules or the need to train the team in China. But we believe we can handle these by planning well and updating our instructions. Question: How long will it take to get all the documentation ready for the China team? Answer: We need about one week to translate the current documents into English. Making videos and further translations might take a bit more time. Question: Will the training materials be understandable for someone who doesn't speak Korean? Answer: Yes, we will translate everything into English first, and then into Chinese if needed, to make sure everyone can understand. Question: How do we ensure the quality of the assembly process remains high after moving to China? Answer: We will train the China team using our updated guides and videos. We will also check the assembly quality regularly. Question: Are there any parts of the assembly that must stay in Korea? Answer: Right now, we think everything can move to China. But we will double-check to make sure. Question: What is our timeline for moving the assembly line to China? Answer: We are still planning, but we will share a timeline as soon as we have it. Question: How will we handle differences in work culture between Korea and China? Answer: We will learn about the work culture in China and adapt our training and management to fit well with the team there. Question: Do we need any special permissions or certifications to start manufacturing in China? Answer: We are checking on this. We will get all the needed permissions and certifications before we start. Question: How will we transfer equipment and materials to China? Answer: We are planning the best way to do this. We will make sure everything is safe and cost-effective. Question: What if we face unexpected challenges during the move? Answer: We will plan carefully and have backup plans. We will solve problems as they come. Question: How will we communicate with the team in China? Answer: We will use English for official communication. We might also use translators when needed to make sure everyone understands. Question: Will there be ongoing support from Korea to the China team? Answer: Yes, we will keep supporting the China team. We can have regular meetings and visits to make sure everything goes well. Question: How will this move affect our delivery times to customers? Answer: We plan to keep delivery times the same, or even improve them by being closer to some of our customers.

item.title: Unit 16. Structuring a Discussion
item.description: look to expand the business into SWOT analysis product line investment opportunity The first item on the agenda is to discuss this SWOT analysis prepared by our analysts. Do you have any thoughts on the information presented in the report? Letâ€™s set aside this topic for now and think about this a bit more before we make a final decision. A. Hello, everyone. Today, weâ€™re here to explore ways to boost our smartphone sales in the U.S. The first item on our agenda is reviewing our pricing strategy. Next, weâ€™ll discuss distribution channelsâ€”whether to switch, expand, or optimize them. Finally, weâ€™ll talk about how to enhance our marketing efforts. Letâ€™s start with the first topic: our pricing strategy. Do you have any thoughts on?Q. When you hold meetings, which types of items do you generally like to discuss first? Why? A. I usually set the first item as either the most important or the most controversial topic to ensure everyone is focused right from the start. However, this approach can vary depending on the purpose of the meeting. For instance, if I know someone critical to the discussion wonâ€™t be able to join on time, I might postpone the important item until later. Ultimately, the order of the agenda depends on the specific circumstances and goals of the meeting.Q. Which items do you generally postpone for discussion later? A. The item that we need a time to figure out, or needed to research. If i judged that there are need of time for other people to figure out about the topic, I may postpone that for later. Well, I usually send attachments or references in advance to let them read that before coming on meeting
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 15. Agreeing and Disagreeing
item.description: cut the budget demographic make up customer base In light of our current budget issues, we need to think about our options. I like your idea of investing in social media advertisement, but Iâ€™m not sure I agree with decreasing our newspaper and TV ad costs. Itâ€™s true that social media is a highly effective way to market, but donâ€™t you think that we have to think about the older demographic as well? Q. Express your opinion to your coworkers. Say you disagree and explain why. A. Given our expanding business in China, I appreciate your suggestion to open an office in Beijing. However, Iâ€™m not entirely convinced about partnering with a local company. Donâ€™t you think our presence in China is already strong enough? We also have many fluent Chinese speakers within our team, so a local partnership might not be necessary. Instead, we should focus on building strong relationships with key figures in the Chinese Communist Party.Q. Have you ever disagreed with your companyâ€™s business strategy? If so, in what ways, and why? A. I wouldnâ€™t say I disagree with my companyâ€™s business strategy, but I often find myself at odds with people who prioritize their personal preferences over the bigger picture. In meetings, even when I prefer to stay quiet, I often feel compelled to voice my opinion that our product needs to be as perfect as possible. Business is like survival in a jungleâ€”no, itâ€™s even more complex than that. In business, the victim often doesnâ€™t realize theyâ€™ve been swallowed by a giant predator until itâ€™s too late.Q. Have you ever had a disagreement with a client? If so, why and how was it resolved? A. Situations like that can happen at any time. It might be related to design, functionality, or even user experience. While I donâ€™t typically communicate with clients since my teamâ€™s work isnâ€™t focused on customer care, if I do receive a customer complaint, I always strive to provide the best possible solution. First, I explain the reason behind the issue, and then I work on offering a reasonable solution that satisfies both sides. If thatâ€™s not possible, I usually propose an option that favors the client.Hello, Yangha! Looking at the sentences you mentioned, I think a few small changes could make them sound more natural and clear. In the first sentence, "We still invest money on that.", it would be more natural to use "in" instead of "on". "We still invest money "in" that." sounds much smoother. In the second sentence, "I feel much on this sentence.", using an expression like "strongly" instead of "much" would make it more natural. "I feel "strongly" about this sentence." In the third sentence, "I will loss my job but i don't feel afraid on that.", using "lose" instead of "loss", and "about that" instead of "on that" would make it more natural. "I will "lose" my job but I don't feel afraid "about" that." In the fourth sentence, "My co-worker suggested to get a partnership to a local company.", using "to partner with" instead of "to get a partnership" would make it more natural. "My co-worker suggested "to partner with" a local company." In the last sentence, "We have many fluent Chinese speaker at our company.", you need to add "s" to "speaker" to make it plural. "We have many fluent Chinese "speakers" at our company." You're doing really well, and I can see you're improving bit by bit. Keep up the good work!
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 6. Review - Working on Projects
item.description: Hello, Yangha! I'll tell you how to make the sentences you mentioned sound more natural. The first sentence, "I experience typhoon too." would sound more natural as "I experienced a typhoon too." "Experience" is a verb that means to have something happen to you, so when you're talking about something that happened in the past, you need to use the past tense, "experienced." And "typhoon" is a natural phenomenon, so it's good to put "a" in front of it. The second sentence, "We will have a global meeting next next week." can be simplified to "We will have a global meeting next week." "Next next week" is a common expression in Korean, but in English, "next week" is enough to convey the meaning. The third sentence, "I think I had a lot of issues with outsourcing." is excellent! This sentence is perfect. The fourth sentence, "Some of our sub-constructors provided with some effects." would sound more natural as "Some of our sub-constructors provided some effects." Using "provided" instead of "provided with" makes the sentence more concise and natural. The last sentence, "We tried to figure out what is the real reason for the bad product." can be changed to "We tried to figure out the real reason for the bad product." Omitting "what is" makes the sentence more concise and natural. Your English skills have really improved! With a little more practice, you'll be able to communicate perfectly in English. Keep it up!
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 1. Announcing a new project
item.description: get a foothold in financial modeling have a consensus convene a meeting adjourn a meeting shelve a topic adopt resolutions have a quorum to vote We have a new smart medical decive in the works. We have a lot groundwork to cover. We might be able to do it if we work around the clock. You managed to come up with quite lengthy sentences to answer most of my questions about todayâ€™s topic. However, please study the use of the word TO. We have new project to develop. â†’ We have a new project to develop. I have a project to build a database to production line. â†’ I have a project to build a database for the production line. I am kind of a hard worker. â†’ Iâ€™m a hard worker. I always feel uncomfortable to speak in English unlike to write in English. I think the why Iâ€™m like this is because of my character, I mean, introverted character. I feel the need of having more chances to speak in English. And it feels like this time is when I have to learn how to have a small talk with other people.I always feel uncomfortable speaking in English, unlike when Iâ€™m writing. I think itâ€™s partly because of my personalityâ€”Iâ€™m more on the introverted side. I feel the need for more opportunities to practice speaking in English, and it seems like now is the right time for me to learn how to make small talk with others.
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 5. Reporting Success
item.description: beta testing functionality user-friendly integrated intradepartmental So far, the feedback has been positive. There are a few things we need to iron out. Weâ€™ll contact each of your departments to get the ball rolling on fixing these problems. Hello, Yangha! I see some areas where you can make your sentences sound more natural. With a few small changes, you can make your writing clearer and more concise. First sentence, "They don't have interest in my project." Instead of "interest." you can use "interested"for a more natural expression. "They are not interested in my project" would be better. Second sentence, "It is too spicy for them to general people." Instead of "general people." "the general public" is a more familiar expression, and instead of "for,"using "for them to be" makes the sentence smoother. How about changing it to "It is too spicy for them to be comfortable with."? Third sentence "We need to minimize the spicy taste."is great! You're doing well. Fourth sentence, "They think computer do everything."Instead of "computer do." using "computers can do"makes the sentence more natural. Try changing it to "They think computers can do everything." Last sentence, "It is always hard to address issue to them." Using "address issues with them" instead of "address issue to them" is more natural, and changing "it is always hard" to "it's always difficult" makes it look cleaner. How about changing it to "It's always difficult to address issues with them."? Yangha, it's great to see your continuous efforts! With a little more practice, you'll become a perfect English speaker! Fighting!
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 14. Making Suggestions
item.description: benefits program take a survey high-end consumer I was looking into ways to improve our membership card. While the initial idea to let everyone receive the same benefits is a good one, I think that it might be better to focus on one specific target group. Why donâ€™t we first take a survey of our competitorsâ€™ high-end consumer rewards programs? Q. Make a suggestion to your team at the meeting. Explain your reasoning in detail. A. Iâ€™ve been looking into ways to increase insurance sales and have a suggestion. a â€œReferral programâ€. It doesnâ€™t simply means that giving temporary discounts to people who refer their friends. Weâ€™ll give special discounts on their monthly insurance payment. That would help build long-term loyalty, rather than just giving short-term perks.Q. At team meetings, do you consider yourself shy or do you speak up and make suggestions about ways to improve projects? A: I have a lot of ideas, and I want to achieve something meaningful in both my current projects and my career. I want to gain more experience, even if it sometimes leads to failure. I always tell myself, â€œOne success is enough to change my life.â€ I might face challenges and fail, but as long as I donâ€™t give up, Iâ€™ll grow stronger and eventually reach the top. Thatâ€™s why I always share my opinions, even when others stay quiet. I understand they might be afraid of failing, but Iâ€™m willing to take the risk.Q. What types of suggestions would you make to the way in which your team operates? A. I would suggest getting rid of outdated customs that are no longer necessary. While we can improve our work by adopting better approaches, we can also make progress by reducing waste in our processes. This doesnâ€™t mean I disregard the traditions we have; I believe there is valuable wisdom in them, and I aim to learn from that to create a better future. At the same time, I understand the importance of maintaining a relaxed work atmosphere because it helps people perform better. Iâ€™m not overly focused on efficiency alone, but itâ€™s important to remember that a companyâ€™s primary goal is to make moneyâ€”thatâ€™s the reason it exists. Thatâ€™s why I prioritize efficiency above all else.Q. What would you improve about employee benefits at your company? A. I want to create a culture that people are excited to be a part of. In our workplace, we should share ideas openly, regardless of our position, and discuss ways to improve both our work environment and our lives. If we can make our work genuinely engaging and meaningful, the concept of â€œwork-life balanceâ€ might not even feel necessary. I enjoy what I do, and I want others to feel the same wayâ€”instead of quietly complaining about the company. We have the power to change our circumstances, and I want everyone to realize that and be part of that change.Hello, Ha Yang! Looking at the sentences you mentioned, I think a few minor edits can make them sound more natural and clear. The first sentence, "They discuss strategy on increasing insurance sales." is almost perfect, but using "for"instead of "on" would make it more natural. "They discuss strategy for increasing insurance sales"sounds better, right? It's a great sentence! The second sentence, "I suggest referral program." can be improved by adding "a" before "referral program." "I suggest a referral program" sounds much more natural. The third sentence, "Many people just want money." is correct, but how about using a more varied expression? "Many people are simply motivated by money" would be a richer and more natural expression. You're doing really well! With small adjustments, you'll develop perfect English skills.I made a lot of mistakes today that I noticed while speaking. If I want to improve my English, I need to put myself in situations where I can speak it more often. I live in Nonsan, and I could use the excuse that there arenâ€™t many opportunities to speak English here. But thatâ€™s just an excuse. I shouldnâ€™t blame my environmentâ€”if I donâ€™t like it, I know itâ€™s up to me to change it.
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 13. Running a meeting
item.description: hang time out touch base Then we can figure out what we can do to fix the issue. How can we figure out the answer to this question without any help? That is the reason why I called this meeting. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining on short notice. We have an urgent matter to discuss today regarding the faulty design of our reclining chair, which has unfortunately caused injuries to a few customers. This is a serious issue, and our priority is to ensure customer safety while protecting our brand reputation. Letâ€™s focus on identifying the problem, finding immediate solutions, and setting a timeline for resolution.Before we start, letâ€™s quickly go over the agenda for todayâ€™s meeting: Review the reported design issue and customer feedback. Brainstorm potential immediate fixes and long-term solutions. Discuss communication with affected customers. Assign action items and propose a follow-up meeting to review progress. Does anyone have additional points to add before we dive in?Q. How often do you have team meetings? What types of issues are usually discussed at those meetings? A. We hold regular meetings three times a weekâ€”on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridaysâ€”where we primarily discuss issues related to the production line. Our focus is on manufacturing battery cells and BESS, and weâ€™re always vigilant about preventing defects.Q. Have you had meetings with foreigners? If so, what types of issues have you had communicating? A. Our headquarters is in Israel, so the team there has a distinctive accent. As you know, we Koreans typically donâ€™t have a noticeable accent, which sometimes makes communication challenging at first. However, once I get used to someoneâ€™s accent and pronunciation, itâ€™s no longer an issue. Time takes care of everything.Q. How do you like to run your meetings? Formally? Informally? Who sets the agenda and how strictly do you stick to it? A. I usually hold meetings in a formal manner. I set the agenda in advance and share it with the attendees beforehand. I don't like wasting time in meetings, so I strive to keep them short and focused. To achieve this, I make sure to stick closely to the agenda.You conveyed your thoughts on the subject we discussed without difficulty. You even used detailed sentences to answer the questions I asked you. However, please add CURRENTLY to your vocabulary bank. It means at the present time. e.g. I'm currently drinking tea. Note: I'm currently drinking tea. -ALTERNATIVE EXPRESSION We held meetings thrice a week. -ALTERNATIVE EXPRESSION The first agenda was about system issues on their website. -COMPLETE SENTENCE
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 12. Review - Socializing
item.description: Our core business focuses on the development, production and marketing of a broad range of pharmaceutical drugs. Letâ€™s grab dinner sometime and catch up properly. Iâ€™m afraid that I wonâ€™t be able to next week. Q. Have you attended any high school or college reunions? How was the experience? What did you discuss with your former classmates? Did you share any fun stories or hear of any? A. I dropped out of high school in my first year, and similarly, I also left college in my freshman year. After that, I attended two colleges in Australia, but now that Iâ€™m in Korea, itâ€™s hard to meet the friends I made back then. I donâ€™t keep in touch with anyone. Maybe Iâ€™m not someone who keeps a wide circle of connections.Q. Do you keep in touch with former colleagues? How often do you meet them? What do you talk about? A. I meet up with my former colleagues about once every few months. We usually drink together until we get wasted. And thatâ€™s all we do, Korean old menâ€™s style. Of course, we have some conversation while drinking. Our topics are commonly works or trivial things weâ€™ve done like as before.Q. What was the last conference or business-networking event that you attended? Did you meet any foreigners? If so, what did you discuss? A. I attended Microsoftâ€™s AI Tour event about six months ago. I met a lot of people there, but we didnâ€™t really have any in-depth discussions. I mostly just listened to the conference and joined in on the activities they had prepared. I went by myself, unlike many others who came with their colleagues as a team. Anyway, there were so many people from all around the world. But I wasnâ€™t quite brave enough to approach them and start a conversation. It felt like I was the only one there on my own.Hello, Yangha! With just a few small changes, you can express yourself even more clearly. The first sentence is almost perfect! Instead of "I'll call you back in the next week." it would be more natural to say "I'll call you back next week." In the second sentence, instead of "Are you available on that time?", it should be "Are you available at that time?". It's more natural to use "at" instead of "on." In the last sentence, instead of "Where you stay?", it should be "Where do you stay?". After "Where." you need to add "do" and before "stay"you need to add "you" to make a complete sentence. Yangha, your English skills have improved so much! If you keep working hard, you'll become even more perfect!
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 4. Oursourcing
item.description: scope of work keep on track with go live request for proposal(RFP) be in good hands Letâ€™s review the statement of work to confirm points so that weâ€™re all on the same page. This project is urgent, so we need a quick turnaround on setting up our website. Would you be able to finish ahead of schedule? Hello, Yangha! After reviewing the sentences you mentioned, I think they can be made even more natural with a few minor corrections! In the first sentence, "There not too many changes.", you need to add "are" after "There" to make it a complete sentence. "There are not too many changes." sounds much more natural. The second sentence, "They are not just useful but also necessary.", is perfectly correct! You did a great job! In the third sentence, "Database should be no malfunction.", it's more natural to use "malfunction-free" instead of "no malfunction". "Database should be malfunction-free." sounds smoother. In the fourth sentence, "Our expectations for database shouldn't be too different.", it's better to add "the" before "database". "Our expectations for the database shouldn't be too different." conveys the meaning more accurately. In the fifth sentence, "We have many contractors because we are manufacturing company.", it's better to change "manufacturing company" to "a manufacturing company". "We have many contractors because we are a manufacturing company." makes for a more natural sentence. Yangha, with just a few grammatical tweaks, these are really great English sentences! Keep practicing and your skills will definitely improve! There not too many changes. â†’ There arenâ€™t too many changes. They are not just useful but also necessary. â†’ Theyâ€™re not just useful but also essential. Database should be no malfunction. â†’ The database should be free of malfunctions. Our expectations for database shouldnâ€™t be too different. â†’ Our expectations for the database shouldnâ€™t differ too much. We have many contractors because we are manufacturing company. â†’ We have many contractors because weâ€™re a manufacturing company.
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 3. Explaining Project Setbacks
item.description: IPO(Initial Public Offering) at this point It seems like weâ€™re going to have to push back the deadline. The problem is that we donâ€™t have much wiggle room with the deadline. Itâ€™s best to have this project finished on time, no matter the cost. The sentences you said today are almost perfect! However, with a few minor adjustments, they can become even clearer and more natural English sentences.The first sentence, â€œDue to bad weather in contractorâ€™s country, the deadline will be delayed.â€ is really well said! If you write â€œthe contractorâ€ instead of â€œcontractorâ€™sâ€, it will be even more perfect. Adding â€œtheâ€ makes it clear that â€œcontractorâ€™sâ€ refers to a specific contractor.The second sentence, â€œI think to that work for 2 days only.â€ sounds a bit awkward. â€œIâ€™ll workâ€ is a more natural expression than â€œI think to that workâ€. â€œIâ€™ll work for 2 days onlyâ€ is a complete sentence.The third sentence, â€œSome people doesnâ€™t meet the requirement for work.â€ should be â€œdonâ€™tâ€ instead of â€œdoesnâ€™tâ€.The fourth sentence, â€œI am still thinking about how should I do?â€ should be â€œtoâ€ instead of â€œshouldâ€. â€œI am still thinking about how to do?â€ sounds more natural.The last sentence, â€œIt very complicated.â€ should be â€œItâ€™s very complicated.â€ English sentences need a subject and a verb to be complete sentences.Youâ€™re doing really well! You seem to be very good at English, Yangha. Keep practicing and you will be able to develop even more fluent English skills.
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 11. Telling a story
item.description: get stuck in traffic Too bad it was for a business trip. I took a gamble thinking that if I took a taxi, I could make it to Grand Central on time. I think Iâ€™d better take the subway. Q. What is the funniest story you have ever heard from a colleague? What was it about? A. It was Halloween recently. One of my friend was asked to attend a Halloween party in Seoul. And He was heard that the dress code is â€œblackâ€. So he decided to wear black tights to make some fun. He thought other people may wear some kind of costume which fit for Halloween. And the day that the party held, he found that it wasnâ€™t a party he expected. He saw everyoneâ€™s in black suit. I donâ€™t know what happened the next, but my friend showed me a picture he took at that party. It was so weird, he stood around the people whoâ€™s in formal suits.â†’ It was Halloween recently, and one of my friends was invited to a Halloween party in Seoul. He was told that the dress code was â€œblack,â€ so, hoping to add a bit of fun, he decided to wear black tights, thinking everyone would show up in Halloween costumes. But when he arrived at the party, it wasnâ€™t quite what heâ€™d expected. He looked around and realized everyone else was dressed in formal black suits. Iâ€™m not sure what happened next, but he showed me a picture from that nightâ€”it was hilarious! There he was, standing in a crowd of people in business attire, completely out of place in his costume.Q. Have you had any interesting situations that occurred while traveling for business? What happened? A. I donâ€™t have any.Q. At lunch, what do you discuss with your coworkers? A. We talked about the business documents of our company which address rules, procedures, and standards of our works. We all know that documents are not good enough, so we discuss how to make it better but we found that itâ€™s really hard to change others, not us. And our roles are not making that kind of docs. So we ended up the talk saying our discussion will goes for nothing.â†’ We talked about our companyâ€™s business documents that outline the rules, procedures, and standards for our work. We all agreed that these documents arenâ€™t quite up to par, so we discussed ways to improve them. But we realized itâ€™s tough to bring about change when it involves others, not just ourselves. Besides, creating these documents isnâ€™t actually our responsibility. In the end, we wrapped up the conversation, admitting that our discussion probably wouldnâ€™t lead to much.Hello, Park Yangha/David! Looking at the sentences you mentioned, I see that a few small adjustments could make them even more natural English sentences!In the first sentence, "It take me to two hours to get the hotel." you should change "It take" to "It takes.""It takes" means "it takes time," while "take" means "to take up time," so it was used incorrectly. "to" indicates a "destination," so changing it to "get to the hotel" would be more natural.In the second sentence, "There are so many bike driver." you should change it to "There are so many bike drivers." "driver" means "driver," and the plural form is "drivers."The third sentence, "Maybe in the next year, I will go to Bohol." is well written, but it could also be written as "Maybe next year, I will go to Bohol." It's a simpler way to express it.In the fourth sentence, "Bohol is one of the best spot for scuba diving." you should change it to "Bohol is one of the best spots for scuba diving." "spot" means "place," and the plural form is "spots."In the last sentence, "The taxi driver was waiting to me." you should change it to "The taxi driver was waiting for me." "waiting for" means "waiting," so using "for" instead of "to" would be more natural.Good job, David! Keep practicing and you'll be able to write perfect English sentences.Iâ€™m able to recognize my mistakes when I speak in English, I still omit â€œsâ€, use singular form very often. I understand how to use â€œsâ€ in a proper way but it seems hard to get used to it. I want to count how many days will it take. As long as I achieve that, nothing matters.I can recognize my mistakes when I speak English, but I still often omit the â€˜sâ€™ and use singular forms. I understand the correct way to use â€˜s,â€™ but itâ€™s hard to get used to. I want to track how many days it will take to improve. As long as I achieve this, nothing else matters.
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 2. Progress Update
item.description: distribution rights exclusive license reach an agreement term sheet final draft agreement We had a meeting this pas Monday to discuss some outstanding issues on the table. Theyâ€™re trying to play hardball. Hopefully weâ€™ll square away any remaining issues then. The grammar mistakes did not alter the meaning of your sentences. You need to improve your usse of prepositions in sentences. By the end of the year We need to negotiate for suppliers for hardware supplies. â†’ We need to negotiate with suppliers for hardware procurement. We have to delay all the schedule. â†’ We need to delay all schedules. I had a project to build database. â†’ I worked on project to build a database. They are not enough to build database by themselves. â†’They donâ€™t have enough expertise to build a database independently.
item.dc:creator: Yangha Park

item.title: Unit 10. Progress Update
item.description: go over last minute worst-case scenario over the phone Iâ€™m afraid that I wonâ€™t be able to next week. I am booked solid with meetings and presentations for the next week or so. Q. Have you ever had issues with trying to meet with someone because of scheduling conflicts? How did you resolve those situations? A. I rarely encounter scheduling conflicts when it comes to business, but sometimes itâ€™s challenging to meet my friends at a time when we can all get together. Unlike me, most of my friends are married, so they have their own families and need to take care of their children as well. This simply means that I have to adjust my schedule to fit theirs, but thatâ€™s no problem as long as we get to meet.Q. What type of software do you use to keep track of your meetings? Why? A. I use several Microsoft applications to manage my schedule and meetings, especially Teams, Planner, and Outlook. Our company provides licenses for these tools, and theyâ€™re quite effective for organizing my time and tasks. That said, I prefer Google Calendar for my personal life. With Google Assistant, I can easily add events by voiceâ€”like saying, â€˜Hey Google, schedule a doctorâ€™s appointment for this Saturday at 9 amâ€™ It then reminds me when the time comes.Q. If an urgent issue came up and you had to reschedule a meeting, how would you handle the problem? A. Iâ€™ll inform the attendees as soon as possible and try to reschedule the meeting after addressing the urgent issue. If theyâ€™re unavailable at the new time, the meeting isnâ€™t the only optionâ€”we can still discuss via email or chat. Another good option is holding a Zoom meeting. I typically have online meetings rather than in-person ones, as my company is international.Even with a few grammatical mistakes, your sentences conveyed your message clearly. Kindly review adjectives and verbs and practice using them correctly. I have to adjust my schedule to fit theirs. â†’ I have to adjust my schedule to fit theirs. Our company provide tool to organize our schedule. â†’ Our company provides tools to organize our schedule. I am just tried to be honest. â†’ I I am just trying to be honest. I will set priority of them. â†’ I will set them as a priority. The organizer give me time. â†’ The organizer gives me time. Itâ€™s my bad habit to omit â€œsâ€ after verbs and nouns even though when I do know how to use it. The practice makes perfect. What I have to is only practice. Iâ€™m thinking how to make the environment around me changed for that practice.Itâ€™s a bad habit of mine to omit the â€˜sâ€™ after verbs and nouns, even though I know how to use it. Practice makes perfectâ€”what I need is simply more practice. Iâ€™m considering how to create an environment that helps me build this habit.

item.title: 2024-02-05 Question of HQ
item.description: Question: Are the rack and container assembly instructions currently available in multiple languages, including Chinese, or do they require translation? Answer: The assembly instructions are currently only available in Korean. We recognize the importance of making these accessible to our team in China and plan to have them translated into English as an intermediary step. This process is expected to take approximately one week. We will explore options for translation into Chinese to ensure clarity and accessibility for all team members involved in the assembly process. Question: Do we have visual aids, such as videos, to supplement the assembly instructions? Answer: At the moment, we do not have video documentation of the assembly process. However, we acknowledge the value of visual aids in enhancing understanding and reducing the potential for errors. We will initiate the creation of video tutorials that detail the assembly process, ensuring that these resources are comprehensive and easy to follow. Question: What specific assembly procedures are currently undertaken by the Korean CM, and are we fully aware of these processes? Answer: The Korean CM handles a range of assembly procedures that are documented in our standard operating procedures. However, it's essential to conduct a thorough review to ensure that all processes are fully captured and up-to-date. We are in the process of auditing these procedures to confirm their completeness and accuracy. Question: Considering the assembly procedures performed by the Korean CM, do we believe it's feasible to replicate these processes in China without significant obstacles? Answer: Based on our initial assessment, we believe that transitioning these assembly processes to China is feasible. The procedures do not require specialized skills that cannot be replicated or taught in China. However, we must ensure that all procedural documentation is current, translated, and adapted as necessary to meet any local regulatory requirements or operational differences. Question: Are there any anticipated challenges or limitations in transferring the assembly line to China, such as differences in regulations, standards, or workforce skills? Answer: While we anticipate a smooth transition overall, we are mindful of potential challenges such as differences in regulatory standards, the need for workforce training, and the adaptation of procedures to local practices. We are committed to conducting a detailed analysis to identify any such challenges early in the process and develop strategies to address them effectively. Question: What will be the approach if there are questions raised during the meeting that cannot be immediately answered? Answer: Should any questions arise that I cannot answer directly, I will take detailed notes and follow up with my direct manager to ensure a timely and accurate response. We are committed to transparency and effective communication throughout this transition process. It's clear from your preparation that while there are areas needing attention, such as the translation of documentation and the creation of visual aids, you have a proactive plan to address these needs. Emphasizing your commitment to a thorough review and update of assembly procedures, along with a strategic approach to overcoming potential challenges, will be key to reassuring the executives of the feasibility and readiness for the transition.Youcan you make it little bit easier? my mother tongue is korean, so some of that sentences are hard to memorize for me.ChatGPTChatGPTCertainly! Let's simplify the responses for your meeting: Question: Do we need to translate the assembly instructions? Are there videos? Answer: Yes, the instructions are only in Korean now. We need to translate them into English, which will take about a week. We don't have videos yet, but we plan to make them to help everyone understand the process better. Question: Can we use the same assembly procedures in China as in Korea? Answer: The procedures we use in Korea can be used in China too. We don't see big problems with moving the assembly there. Most tasks don't need special skills. But, we need to update and translate our instructions to make sure everyone can follow them. Question: What problems might we face moving to China? Answer: We might face some challenges, like different rules or the need to train the team in China. But we believe we can handle these by planning well and updating our instructions. Question: How long will it take to get all the documentation ready for the China team? Answer: We need about one week to translate the current documents into English. Making videos and further translations might take a bit more time. Question: Will the training materials be understandable for someone who doesn't speak Korean? Answer: Yes, we will translate everything into English first, and then into Chinese if needed, to make sure everyone can understand. Question: How do we ensure the quality of the assembly process remains high after moving to China? Answer: We will train the China team using our updated guides and videos. We will also check the assembly quality regularly. Question: Are there any parts of the assembly that must stay in Korea? Answer: Right now, we think everything can move to China. But we will double-check to make sure. Question: What is our timeline for moving the assembly line to China? Answer: We are still planning, but we will share a timeline as soon as we have it. Question: How will we handle differences in work culture between Korea and China? Answer: We will learn about the work culture in China and adapt our training and management to fit well with the team there. Question: Do we need any special permissions or certifications to start manufacturing in China? Answer: We are checking on this. We will get all the needed permissions and certifications before we start. Question: How will we transfer equipment and materials to China? Answer: We are planning the best way to do this. We will make sure everything is safe and cost-effective. Question: What if we face unexpected challenges during the move? Answer: We will plan carefully and have backup plans. We will solve problems as they come. Question: How will we communicate with the team in China? Answer: We will use English for official communication. We might also use translators when needed to make sure everyone understands. Question: Will there be ongoing support from Korea to the China team? Answer: Yes, we will keep supporting the China team. We can have regular meetings and visits to make sure everything goes well. Question: How will this move affect our delivery times to customers? Answer: We plan to keep delivery times the same, or even improve them by being closer to some of our customers.

Copy and Paste í•„ìš”.) (ë‚´ê°€ ì‚¬ìš©í•œ ë¼ì´ë¸ŒëŸ¬ë¦¬ëŠ” pandas, numpy, matplotlib, scipy ì´ë‹¤.) Python script editorì˜ ì™¸ë¶€ IDE ê¸°ëŠ¥ì„ ì¨ì„œ scriptë¥¼ ì—´ì–´ë³´ë©´,
ìœ„ì™€ ê°™ì€ í™”ë©´ì„ ë³¼ ìˆ˜ ìžˆë‹¤. ê¸°ë³¸ìœ¼ë¡œ os, uuid, matplotlib, pandsë¥¼ import í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì„ ë³¼ ìˆ˜ ìžˆë‹¤. ê·¸ë¦¬ê³  ì•„ëž˜ì˜ datasetì„ ë³´ë©´ ë°ì´í„°ë¥¼ ìž„ì‹œë¡œ csvë¡œ ì €ìž¥í•˜ê³  pandasë¡œ í”„ë ˆìž„ì„ ë§Œë“¤ì–´ ì¤€ë‹¤ëŠ” ê±¸ ì•Œ ìˆ˜ ìžˆë‹¤. ê·¸ë¦¬ê³  ë°ì´í„°ì…‹ì—ì„œ ì¤‘ë³µê°’ì„ ì‚­ì œí•˜ë„ë¡ ê¸°ë³¸ ì„¤ì •ë˜ì–´ ìžˆìœ¼ë¯€ë¡œ, ë§Œì•½ ë°ì´í„°ê°€ ì˜ë¯¸ ìžˆëŠ” ì¤‘ë³µê°’ì„ ê°–ê³  ìžˆë‹¤ë©´ ê³ ìœ  idë¥¼ ìƒì„±í•˜ì—¬ ì§€ì›Œì§€ì§€ ì•Šë„ë¡ ë§‰ì•„ì£¼ë©´ ëœë‹¤.(ë‚˜ëŠ” Power BI Query Editorì—ì„œ Indexì—´ì„ ì¶”ê°€í•´ì¤¬ë‹¤.)ì´ì œ ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ìž‘ì„±í•˜ë©´ ëœë‹¤. í•œê°€ì§€ ì£¼ì˜í•  ì ì€ ìœ„ì˜ ì½”ë“œì˜ ì£¼ì„ìœ¼ë¡œ ì•ˆë‚´ëœ ë‚´ìš©ì²˜ëŸ¼ ì™¸ë¶€IDEì—ì„œ ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ìž‘ì„±í•˜ê³  ì €ìž¥í•œë‹¤ê³  í•´ë„ Power BIì˜ Python script editorì— ì ìš©ë˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì€ ì•„ë‹ˆë‹¤. ìž‘ì„±í•œ ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ë³µì‚¬í•´ì„œ Python script editorì— ë¶™ì—¬ë„£ê¸° í•˜ëŠ” ìž‘ì—…ì´ í•„ìš”í•˜ë‹¤.import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt from scipy import stats # Define the variables and their specification limits variables = [ { 'name': 'Distance1', 'lsl': 180, 'usl': 182, 'xlabel': 'Distance1' }, { 'name': 'Distance2', 'lsl': 354, 'usl': 356, 'xlabel': 'Distance2' }, { 'name': 'Distance3', 'lsl': 180, 'usl': 182, 'xlabel': 'Distance3' }, { 'name': 'Distance4', 'lsl': 354, 'usl': 356, 'xlabel': 'Distance4' } ] # Determine the number of plots n_vars = len(variables) cols = 2 rows = (n_vars + cols - 1) // cols # Calculate rows based on number of variables # Create the figure and axes fig, axes = plt.subplots(rows, cols, figsize=(10 * cols, 6 * rows)) # Flatten axes array for easy indexing axes = axes.flatten() # Loop over variables and create plots for i, var in enumerate(variables): ax = axes[i] var_name = var['name'] lsl = var['lsl'] usl = var['usl'] xlabel = var['xlabel'] # Check if the variable exists in the dataset if var_name not in dataset.columns: continue data = dataset[var_name].dropna() # Remove NaN values # Calculate statistics mean = data.mean() std_dev = data.std() # Calculate Cp and Cpk cp = (usl - lsl) / (6 * std_dev) cpu = (usl - mean) / (3 * std_dev) cpl = (mean - lsl) / (3 * std_dev) cpk = min(cpu, cpl) # Plot histogram ax.hist(data, bins=50, density=True, alpha=0.7, color='skyblue') # Plot normal distribution curve x = np.linspace(lsl - 3*std_dev, usl + 3*std_dev, 100) ax.plot(x, stats.norm.pdf(x, mean, std_dev), 'g-', lw=2) # Vertical lines for LSL, USL, and Mean ax.axvline(lsl, color='r', linestyle='dashed', linewidth=2) ax.axvline(usl, color='r', linestyle='dashed', linewidth=2) ax.axvline(mean, color='k', linestyle='dashed', linewidth=2) # Text annotations ax.text(0.05, 0.95, f'Cpk: {cpk:.2f}', transform=ax.transAxes, verticalalignment='top', fontsize=13, fontweight='bold') ax.text(0.05, 0.88, f'Cp: {cp:.2f}', transform=ax.transAxes, verticalalignment='top') ax.text(0.05, 0.83, f'Mean: {mean:.2f}', transform=ax.transAxes, verticalalignment='top') ax.text(0.05, 0.78, f'Std.Dev: {std_dev:.2f}', transform=ax.transAxes, verticalalignment='top') ax.text(0.05, 0.73, f'LSL: {lsl:.1f}', transform=ax.transAxes, verticalalignment='top') ax.text(0.05, 0.68, f'USL: {usl:.1f}', transform=ax.transAxes, verticalalignment='top') # Labels and title ax.set_xlabel(xlabel) ax.set_ylabel('Frequency') ax.set_title(f'{xlabel} - Cpk Analysis', fontsize=18, fontweight='bold') # Set x-axis limits to focus on the area around LSL and USL x_margin = (usl - lsl) * 0.2 ax.set_xlim(lsl - x_margin, usl + x_margin) # Hide any unused subplots for j in range(i + 1, len(axes)): fig.delaxes(axes[j]) # Adjust layout plt.tight_layout() plt.show() ê°ì²´ ì•ˆì— 2ì—´ë¡œ Plotì˜ ê°¯ìˆ˜(ìœ„ variables ë¦¬ìŠ¤íŠ¸ì˜ ë”•ì…”ë„ˆë¦¬ ê°¯ìˆ˜)ë§Œí¼ ê·¸ëž˜í”„ê°€ í‘œì‹œë˜ë„ë¡ í–ˆë‹¤. í‘œë³¸ ë°ì´í„°ì˜ ê°¯ìˆ˜ì— ë”°ë¼ binsì˜ ê°’ì„ ìˆ˜ì •í•´ ì¤€ë‹¤.ax.hist(data, bins=50, density=True, alpha=0.7, color='skyblue') ê·¸ë¦¬ê³  ì¶œë ¥ëœ ê·¸ëž˜í”„ë¥¼ ë³´ê³  x_margin = (usl - lsl) * 0.2 ax.set_xlim(lsl - x_margin, usl + x_margin) ì˜ margin ê°’ì„ ìˆ˜ì •í•´ ì¤€ë‹¤. (ê°’ì´ USL, LSLê³¼ ë™ë–¨ì–´ì§ˆ ê²½ìš°ëŠ” ê·¸ëž˜í”„ê°€ ì´ìƒí•˜ê²Œ í‘œì‹œë  ìˆ˜ ìžˆìœ¼ë‹ˆ ì•„ì˜ˆ ìˆ˜ì‹ì„ ìˆ˜ì •í•˜ëŠ” ê²ƒì´ ë‚«ë‹¤.)ì•„ëž˜ì™€ ê°™ì´ ì¶œë ¥ëœ ê²°ê³¼ë¬¼ì„ í™•ì¸í•œë‹¤. ê²°ê³¼ë¬¼ì„ ë³´ê³  ìˆ˜ì •ì´ í•„ìš”í•œ ë¶€ë¶„ì´ë‚˜ ì¶”ê°€í•  ë‚´ìš©ì´ ìžˆìœ¼ë©´ ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ìˆ˜ì •í•´ì¤€ë‹¤.

item.title: Excel VBA_í…Œì´ë¸” êµ¬ì¡° ë³€ê²½ ìžë™í™”
item.description:
ìƒì‚° ê³„íšì„ ì§œëŠ” íŒ€ì—ì„œ ìœ„ì™€ ê°™ì´ êµ¬ì¡°í™”ë˜ì§€ ì•Šì€ í…Œì´ë¸” í˜•ì‹ìœ¼ë¡œ ë°°í¬ë¥¼ í•œë‹¤. í˜„ìž¬ ë‚´ê°€ ë§Œë“  Databaseì— ê·¸ëŒ€ë¡œ ìž…ë ¥í•  ìˆ˜ ì—†ëŠ” í˜•íƒœì˜ ë°ì´í„°ì´ê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì— ì •í˜•í™”ëœ í…Œì´ë¸”ë¡œ ë°”ê¿”ì¤„ í•„ìš”ê°€ ìžˆì—ˆë‹¤. ì•„ëž˜ì™€ ê°™ì´ ìƒˆë¡œìš´ ì—‘ì…€ íŒŒì¼ì„ ë§Œë“¤ê³ , ê³„íší‘œì—ì„œ í•„ìš”í•œ ë¶€ë¶„ë§Œ ë³µì‚¬í•˜ì—¬ ë¶™ì—¬ ë„£ì—ˆë‹¤. ê·¸ë¦¬ê³  ì•„ëž˜ì™€ ê°™ì´ VBA ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ìž‘ì„±í•œë‹¤.Sub TransDataEXECUTE_OLD() Dim ws As Worksheet, achProcessWs As Worksheet Dim lastRow As Long, lastCol As Long, i As Long, j As Long Dim newWs As Worksheet, newRow As Long, achProcessRow As Long Dim dataArray As Variant, achProcessArray As Variant Dim planId As Long Dim typeCol As Integer, achProcessCol As Integer Dim po As String, pn As String, wo As String Application.ScreenUpdating = False ' Turn off screen updating Application.Calculation = xlCalculationManual ' Turn off automatic calculations Set ws = ThisWorkbook.Sheets("Original") ' Sheet with original data Set achProcessWs = ThisWorkbook.Sheets("AchProcess") ' Sheet with AchProcess data Set newWs = ThisWorkbook.Sheets.Add(After:=ThisWorkbook.Sheets(ThisWorkbook.Sheets.Count)) newWs.Name = "Transformed" lastRow = ws.Cells(ws.Rows.Count, "A").End(xlUp).Row ' Find the last row lastCol = ws.Cells(1, ws.Columns.Count).End(xlToLeft).Column ' Find the last column achProcessRow = achProcessWs.Cells(achProcessWs.Rows.Count, "A").End(xlUp).Row ' Last row in AchProcess sheet ' Copy headers and add new headers newWs.Range(newWs.Cells(1, 1), newWs.Cells(1, 8)).Value = ws.Range(ws.Cells(1, 1), ws.Cells(1, 8)).Value newWs.Cells(1, 9).Value = "Date" newWs.Cells(1, 10).Value = "PlanQ'ty" newWs.Cells(1, 11).Value = "Plan_ID" newWs.Cells(1, 12).Value = "AchProcess" newWs.Cells(1, 13).Value = "W/O" ' Add W/O header newRow = 2 ' Starting row for the new sheet dataArray = ws.Range(ws.Cells(1, 1), ws.Cells(lastRow, lastCol)).Value ' Array for data achProcessArray = achProcessWs.Range(achProcessWs.Cells(1, 1), achProcessWs.Cells(achProcessRow, 2)).Value ' Array for AchProcess data planId = 1 ' Starting Plan ID typeCol = 2 ' Assuming Type is in the second column For i = 2 To UBound(dataArray, 1) ' Loop through rows For j = 12 To UBound(dataArray, 2) ' Loop through date columns If dataArray(i, j) <> "-" And dataArray(i, j) <> "" Then ' Check for non-empty and non-dash values ' Copy the first 11 columns newWs.Range(newWs.Cells(newRow, 1), newWs.Cells(newRow, 8)).Value = Application.Index(dataArray, i, Array(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8)) newWs.Cells(newRow, 9).Value = dataArray(1, j) newWs.Cells(newRow, 10).Value = dataArray(i, j) newWs.Cells(newRow, 11).Value = "P" & planId ' Assigning unique Plan_ID ' Search for AchProcess based on Type For achProcessCol = 1 To UBound(achProcessArray, 1) If achProcessArray(achProcessCol, 1) = dataArray(i, typeCol) Then newWs.Cells(newRow, 12).Value = achProcessArray(achProcessCol, 2) ' Assign AchProcess Exit For End If Next achProcessCol ' Generate W/O po = dataArray(i, 5) ' Assuming P/O is in the 6th column pn = dataArray(i, 6) ' Assuming PN is in the 7th column wo = po & Left(pn, 3) & Right(pn, 5) newWs.Cells(newRow, 13).Value = wo ' Assign W/O newRow = newRow + 1 planId = planId + 1 ' Increment Plan ID End If Next j Next i newWs.Columns("I:I").Select Selection.NumberFormat = "yyyy-mm-dd" Application.ScreenUpdating = True ' Turn on screen updating Application.Calculation = xlCalculationAutomatic ' Turn on automatic calculations End Sub W/Oë¼ëŠ” ì—´ì€, ê³„íšì— Primary Keyê°€ ì—†ê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì—(P/O í•˜ë‚˜ì— ì˜¨ê°– ì œí’ˆì´ ë‹¤ ì—®ì—¬ ìžˆë‹¤.) ê´€ê³„í˜• ë°ì´í„°ë² ì´ìŠ¤ì—ì„œ ë°ì´í„°ê°€ ê¼¬ì¸ë‹¤. ê·¸ëž˜ì„œ ê¶ì—¬ì§€ì±…ìœ¼ë¡œ 3ì—´ ê²°í•© í‚¤ë¥¼ ìž„ì˜ë¡œ ë¶€ì—¬í–ˆë‹¤.(ë‚˜ì¤‘ì— ì•ˆ ê±°ì§€ë§Œ ì´ë ‡ê²Œ 3ì¤‘ ê²°í•© í‚¤ë¥¼ ì‚¬ìš©í–ˆëŠ”ë°ë„ ì¤‘ë³µëœ í‚¤ê°€ ë‚˜ì™”ë‹¤â€¦ ë°ì´í„° ì •ê·œí™”ì˜ ì¤‘ìš”ì„±) ì´ ë²„ì „ì„ ì²˜ìŒì— ìž‘ì„±í•  ë•ŒëŠ” Power BIì™€ ì—°ê²°í•œ ì›ë³¸ì„ ExcelíŒŒì¼ë¡œ ê´€ë¦¬í–ˆê¸° ë•Œë¬¸ì— ë³„ë„ì˜ IDë¥¼ ë¶€ì—¬í•  í•„ìš”ê°€ ìžˆì—ˆë‹¤.(ì•„ë‹ˆë©´ Power BIì˜ Query Editorì—ì„œ ì¸ë±ì‹± ì—´ì„ ì¶”ê°€í•´ë„ ëì§€ë§Œ ë‹¹ì‹œì—ëŠ” ëª°ëžë‹¤.) achProcessëŠ” ìƒì‚° ì‹¤ì ì„ ì§‘ê³„í•˜ëŠ” ê³µì •(ì˜ˆë¥¼ ë“¤ì–´ í¬ìž¥)ì´ ë¬´ì—‡ì¸ì§€ achProcess ì‹œíŠ¸ì˜ í…Œì´ë¸”ì—ì„œ ì œí’ˆ íƒ€ìž…ì„ ê¸°ë°˜ìœ¼ë¡œ ì‹¤ì  ì§‘ê³„ ê³µì •ì„ ê²€ìƒ‰í•´ì„œ êµ¬ì¡° ë³€ê²½ëœ ë°ì´í„°ì— ì¶”ê°€í•˜ë„ë¡ í–ˆë‹¤.ì´ì œ ì•„ëž˜ì™€ ê°™ì´ ë°ì´í„°ë¥¼ ë¶™ì—¬ ë„£ê³  ì´ì œ ë§¤í¬ë¡œë¥¼ ì‹¤í–‰í•˜ë©´,
ì´ë ‡ê²Œ ì„¸ë¡œ ë°°ì—´ë¡œ ë³€í™˜ëœ ë°ì´í„°ê°€ ë‚˜ì˜¨ë‹¤. ì´ê±¸ ë°ì´í„°ë² ì´ìŠ¤ ë°ì´í„°ë¡œ ì¶”ê°€í•´ì£¼ë©´ Power BIì— ë°˜ì˜ëœë‹¤.

item.description: ë‚ ì§œ í•„í„°ë§ ê¸°ëŠ¥: ì—°ë„, ì›”, ì£¼ì°¨, ë‚ ì§œ í•„í„°ë§ì„ ì¶”ê°€. ìƒì‚° ì°¨íŠ¸: ìƒì‚°ìˆ˜ëŸ‰, ë¶ˆëŸ‰ìˆ˜ëŸ‰ì„ ëˆ„ì ë§‰ëŒ€ ê·¸ëž˜í”„ë¡œ í‘œì‹œ. ë¶ˆëŸ‰ìœ¨ ê·¸ëž˜í”„: ë¶ˆëŸ‰ìœ¨ì„ ì„ ê·¸ëž˜í”„ë¡œ í‘œì‹œ. í”„ë¦¬ížˆí„° ì˜¨ë„ ê¸°ë°˜ Cpk ê·¸ëž˜í”„: ê³µì • íŒŒë¼ë¯¸í„°ì˜ ë³€í™”ë¥¼ ê°ì§€í•˜ëŠ” ê·¸ëž˜í”„ë¥¼ cpkë¡œ í‘œì‹œ. ë°ì´í„°ë² ì´ìŠ¤ ì‹¤ì‹œê°„ ì—…ë°ì´íŠ¸: 1ë¶„ë§ˆë‹¤ ë°ì´í„°ë² ì´ìŠ¤ì—ì„œ ìƒˆë¡œìš´ ë°ì´í„° í™•ì¸ í›„ ì—…ë°ì´íŠ¸. 2ì—´ë¡œ ì°¨íŠ¸ ë°°ì¹˜: í•œ í™”ë©´ì— 2ì—´ë¡œ ì°¨íŠ¸ë¥¼ ë°°ì¹˜. ì´ì œ ë‹¨ê³„ë³„ë¡œ ì½”ë“œë¥¼ ìž‘ì„±í•©ë‹ˆë‹¤:import numpy as np import plotly.graph_objects as go from scipy.stats import norm from sqlalchemy import create_engine import urllib.parse import pandas as pd from dash import dcc, html import dash from dash.dependencies import Input, Output import time # ë°ì´í„°ë² ì´ìŠ¤ ì ‘ì† ì •ë³´ ì„¤ì • username = urllib.parse.quote_plus('test') password = urllib.parse.quote_plus('0908') host = 'localhost' port = '5432' database = 'postgres' DATABASE_URL = f"postgresql://{username}:{password}@{host}:{port}/{database}" engine = create_engine(DATABASE_URL) # ëŒ€ì‹œë³´ë“œ ì„¤ì • app = dash.Dash(__name__) # ì‹¤ì‹œê°„ ë°ì´í„° ì—…ë°ì´íŠ¸ í•¨ìˆ˜ def load_data(): query = "SELECT * FROM production_data" # í…Œì´ë¸”ì˜ ì´ë¦„ df = pd.read_sql(query, engine) return df # ë ˆì´ì•„ì›ƒ ì„¤ì • app.layout = html.Div([ html.H1("WP Pouch Production Dashboard), # ë‚ ì§œ í•„í„° dcc.DatePickerRange( id='date-picker', start_date=pd.Timestamp.today().floor('D') - pd.DateOffset(months=1), end_date=pd.Timestamp.today().floor('D'), display_format='YYYY-MM-DD' ), # ì°¨íŠ¸ë“¤ html.Div([ dcc.Graph(id='production-chart'), dcc.Graph(id='defect-rate-chart') ], style={'display': 'flex', 'flex-direction': 'row'}), html.Div([ dcc.Graph(id='cpk-chart') ], style={'display': 'flex', 'flex-direction': 'row'}) ]) # ë°ì´í„° ì—…ë°ì´íŠ¸ ë° ì°¨íŠ¸ ìƒì„± ì½œë°± @app.callback( [Output('production-chart', 'figure'), Output('defect-rate-chart', 'figure'), Output('cpk-chart', 'figure')], [Input('date-picker', 'start_date'), Input('date-picker', 'end_date')] ) def update_charts(start_date, end_date): # ë°ì´í„° ë¶ˆëŸ¬ì˜¤ê¸° df = load_data() # ë‚ ì§œ í•„í„° ì ìš© mask = (df['date_of_entry'] >= start_date) & (df['date_of_entry'] <= end_date) filtered_df = df.loc[mask] # 1. ìƒì‚° ì°¨íŠ¸ production_chart = create_production_chart(filtered_df) # 2. ë¶ˆëŸ‰ìœ¨ ì°¨íŠ¸ defect_rate_chart = create_defect_rate_chart(filtered_df) # 3. Cpk ì°¨íŠ¸ cpk_chart = create_cpk_chart(filtered_df) return production_chart, defect_rate_chart, cpk_chart # ì°¨íŠ¸ ìƒì„± í•¨ìˆ˜ë“¤ (ì•„ëž˜ì—ì„œ êµ¬í˜„) def create_production_chart(df): df['is_ng'] = df['cell_assy_ok_ng'] == 'NG' production_summary = df.groupby('date_column').agg( production_count=('id', 'count'), defect_count=('is_ng', 'sum') ).reset_index() production_summary['good_count'] = production_summary['production_count'] - production_summary['defect_count'] fig = go.Figure() fig.add_trace(go.Bar( x=production_summary['date_column'], y=production_summary['good_count'], name='Good', marker_color='blue' )) fig.add_trace(go.Bar( x=production_summary['date_column'], y=production_summary['defect_count'], name='NG', marker_color='red' )) fig.update_layout( title="Production Chart (Good vs NG)", barmode='stack' ) return fig def create_defect_rate_chart(df): df['is_ng'] = df['cell_assy_ok_ng'] == 'NG' production_summary = df.groupby('date_column').agg( production_count=('id', 'count'), defect_count=('is_ng', 'sum') ).reset_index() production_summary['defect_rate'] = (production_summary['defect_count'] / production_summary['production_count']) * 100 fig = go.Figure() fig.add_trace(go.Scatter( x=production_summary['date_column'], y=production_summary['defect_rate'], mode='lines+markers', name='ë¶ˆëŸ‰ìœ¨' )) fig.update_layout( title="ë¶ˆëŸ‰ìœ¨ (%)", yaxis_title="ë¶ˆëŸ‰ìœ¨ (%)" ) return fig def create_cpk_chart(df): df['temp_diff'] = abs(df['preheater_current_temp'] - df['preheater_setting_temp']) mean_temp = df['preheater_current_temp'].mean() sigma_temp = df['preheater_current_temp'].std() usl = df['preheater_setting_temp'].mean() * 1.05 lsl = df['preheater_setting_temp'].mean() * 0.95 fig = go.Figure() # ë¶„í¬ ê³¡ì„ x = np.linspace(mean_temp - 4 * sigma_temp, mean_temp + 4 * sigma_temp, 100) y = norm.pdf(x, mean_temp, sigma_temp) fig.add_trace(go.Scatter( x=x, y=y, mode='lines', name='Current Temperature Distribution', line=dict(color='blue') )) # USL, LSL, ì¤‘ì•™ê°’ fig.add_shape(type='line', x0=lsl, x1=lsl, y0=0, y1=max(y), line=dict(color='red', dash='dash')) fig.add_shape(type='line', x0=usl, x1=usl, y0=0, y1=max(y), line=dict(color='red', dash='dash')) fig.add_shape(type='line', x0=mean_temp, x1=mean_temp, y0=0, y1=max(y), line=dict(color='green', dash='dash')) fig.update_layout( title="Cpk ê·¸ëž˜í”„", xaxis_title="í”„ë¦¬ížˆí„° ì˜¨ë„", yaxis_title="ë°€ë„", ) return fig # 1ë¶„ë§ˆë‹¤ ë°ì´í„° ì—…ë°ì´íŠ¸ @app.callback( Output('interval-component', 'n_intervals'), [Input('interval-component', 'n_intervals')] ) def update_data(n): # 1ë¶„ë§ˆë‹¤ ì‹¤í–‰ load_data() app.layout.children.append( dcc.Interval( id='interval-component', interval=60*1000, # 1ë¶„ë§ˆë‹¤ n_intervals=0 ) ) ###4. ëŒ€ì‹œ ë””ë²„ê·¸ ëª¨ë“œ ì‹¤í–‰if __name__ == '__main__': app.run_server(debug=True) #Databases/PostgreSQL #Programming/Python #DataVisualization/Dash #QualityControl/CpkAnalysis #RealTime/Updates

item.title: Kirkus Reviews - the Unbearable lightness of being
item.description: "Unbearable Lightness of Being" by Milan Kundera is a profoundly insightful novel that delves into the intricate nuances of love, politics, and existential dilemmas. Set against the backdrop of the 1968 Prague Spring and its subsequent Soviet-led invasion, the story primarily follows the lives of Tomas, a surgeon and a philanderer, and Tereza, his wife and a photographer, along with other central characters like Sabina, Tomas's mistress, and Franz, her lover.Kundera masterfully explores the dichotomy of lightness and weight, a central theme of the novel. This philosophical concept questions whether life is a fleeting, insignificant occurrence (lightness) or a series of meaningful events and responsibilities (weight). Through his characters, Kundera examines how each approach impacts one's existence and relationships.The novel is also remarkable for its exploration of political and historical contexts, particularly the impact of Czechoslovakia's political turmoil on its citizens. It provides a poignant commentary on how external political forces can intrude into and shape personal lives, relationships, and moral decisions.Moreover, Kundera's narrative style, characterized by its introspective and often non-linear approach, invites readers to engage deeply with the characters' psychological landscapes. This introspection is balanced with moments of irony and humor, making the novel as intellectually stimulating as it is emotionally resonant.In terms of its impact on literature and culture, "The Unbearable Lightness of Being" stands out for its philosophical depth, its innovative narrative structure, and its profound exploration of human emotions and the existential plight. It remains a vital read for anyone interested in the intersections of love, personal freedom, and the inescapable influence of historical and political contexts on human life.https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/milan-kundera/the-unbearable-lightness-of-being/

item.title: Kirkus Reviews - the Unbearable lightness of being
item.description: "Unbearable Lightness of Being" by Milan Kundera is a profoundly insightful novel that delves into the intricate nuances of love, politics, and existential dilemmas. Set against the backdrop of the 1968 Prague Spring and its subsequent Soviet-led invasion, the story primarily follows the lives of Tomas, a surgeon and a philanderer, and Tereza, his wife and a photographer, along with other central characters like Sabina, Tomas's mistress, and Franz, her lover.Kundera masterfully explores the dichotomy of lightness and weight, a central theme of the novel. This philosophical concept questions whether life is a fleeting, insignificant occurrence (lightness) or a series of meaningful events and responsibilities (weight). Through his characters, Kundera examines how each approach impacts one's existence and relationships.The novel is also remarkable for its exploration of political and historical contexts, particularly the impact of Czechoslovakia's political turmoil on its citizens. It provides a poignant commentary on how external political forces can intrude into and shape personal lives, relationships, and moral decisions.Moreover, Kundera's narrative style, characterized by its introspective and often non-linear approach, invites readers to engage deeply with the characters' psychological landscapes. This introspection is balanced with moments of irony and humor, making the novel as intellectually stimulating as it is emotionally resonant.In terms of its impact on literature and culture, "The Unbearable Lightness of Being" stands out for its philosophical depth, its innovative narrative structure, and its profound exploration of human emotions and the existential plight. It remains a vital read for anyone interested in the intersections of love, personal freedom, and the inescapable influence of historical and political contexts on human life.https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/milan-kundera/the-unbearable-lightness-of-being/

item.title: Kirkus Reviews - the Unbearable lightness of being
item.description: "Unbearable Lightness of Being" by Milan Kundera is a profoundly insightful novel that delves into the intricate nuances of love, politics, and existential dilemmas. Set against the backdrop of the 1968 Prague Spring and its subsequent Soviet-led invasion, the story primarily follows the lives of Tomas, a surgeon and a philanderer, and Tereza, his wife and a photographer, along with other central characters like Sabina, Tomas's mistress, and Franz, her lover.Kundera masterfully explores the dichotomy of lightness and weight, a central theme of the novel. This philosophical concept questions whether life is a fleeting, insignificant occurrence (lightness) or a series of meaningful events and responsibilities (weight). Through his characters, Kundera examines how each approach impacts one's existence and relationships.The novel is also remarkable for its exploration of political and historical contexts, particularly the impact of Czechoslovakia's political turmoil on its citizens. It provides a poignant commentary on how external political forces can intrude into and shape personal lives, relationships, and moral decisions.Moreover, Kundera's narrative style, characterized by its introspective and often non-linear approach, invites readers to engage deeply with the characters' psychological landscapes. This introspection is balanced with moments of irony and humor, making the novel as intellectually stimulating as it is emotionally resonant.In terms of its impact on literature and culture, "The Unbearable Lightness of Being" stands out for its philosophical depth, its innovative narrative structure, and its profound exploration of human emotions and the existential plight. It remains a vital read for anyone interested in the intersections of love, personal freedom, and the inescapable influence of historical and political contexts on human life.https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/milan-kundera/the-unbearable-lightness-of-being/
